description: Players compete to be the first to reach 100 "pumpkins" by doing the most unusual tasks: saying a word to other players with a mouth full with water, drawing with a soft pencil, and so on. Fun for grownup children Ages 14 and up

name: Allegro
description:
ALLEGRO is a music game requiring no previous musical experience, but may be of value in learning the rudiments of musical notation.

Components:

Gameboard - with an outer track depicting 28 composers and a central wheel containing a list of actions (forfeits / bonuses etc).
28 Composer cards - each depicting a composer and matching one on the board. Each is colored coded to represent the lengths of different musical notes and has a number from 1 to 6. Each card also has a short biography of the composer, but this is not relevant to the game.
6 playing pieces - each representing a different musical instrument (harp, violin, trumpet drum, piano and saxophone)
1 colored die - each face has a different color and musical note
1 numerical die - D6
Paper money - in 6 colors - each with a musical symbol and name (as for the composers and colored die).
Money converter card - this gives the relative value of the each color of paper money.

Players throw the two dice which determine a position (composer) on the board to which the players playing piece is moved (i.e. 5 Green is Dvorak). Money is also earned according to the same dice roll - 5 Green means that 5 pieces of green money are received.

If the Composer is owned by another player then a forfeit must be paid. If not the Composer may be bought.

During his turn a player may also purchase up to 10 pieces of music from each Composer that they own.

A supplementary action (forfeit, movement or bonus) is also determined from the inner wheel based on the same dice roll (5 Green for example is "Pass to Bach").

Play proceeds in such a way - move, receive money, purchase a composer/pay a forfeit, purchase works, central wheel action - until one player has purchased 6 Composers - one in each color and amassed 10 pieces of music from each of the composers owned.
An advanced version of the game introduces a quiz book round in which players are also asked to attempt a definition of a musical phrase or term. A correct answer results in earning more money.

name: Streetsafe
description:
STREETSAFE is designed by Trevor Roberts, a former British Ju Jitsu Champion. It was developed to teach people how to be safe on the street.

The aim of the game is to visit four places in the city (determined by a deal of "destination cards") whilst avoiding dangerous areas such as dark alley or parks.

Prior to commencing their journey players may elect to undertake training in the martial arts thereby providing them with a better chance of defining themselves against any dangers that they may come across during that journey.

When they decide to start players move around the game board as the result of a roll of a D6. On landing on a "Risk" square a card is drawn and the instructions on that card followed (i.e. go back 4 spaces, go to the nearest "Streetwise" space...).

On landing on a "Streetwise" space a card is drawn which presents the player with a scenario such as being faced by one man with a large stick. The player then has the option of running away (normally the best course of action) or staying. The results of the encounter are determined by the choice made and the level of self-defense training achieved by the player.

The first player to visit his/her four destinations and return the the Bus Depot (start) is the winner.

name: Castles
description:
From the Kaothic Games website:

You Need:

* A piecepack set
* Pen and paper

The object of Castles is to collect the most gold over a predetermined number of rounds (equal to the number of players, one different a player starts each round). You must place your castle nearest most valuable resource tiles and try to avoid hostile tiles, which deplete the gold you collect from the region. To control tiles you must deploy your armies over the terrain. To count your gains you must attend the tile where you placed your castle and four orthogonally adjacent tiles to that tile.

After all rounds, the player with the most gold wins.
publishers: (Web published), Ediciones Efimeras, Kaothic Games, Piecepack Games

name: Zombie Plague: Twitchers
description:
An expansion to Zombie Plague by Hackwerks. Based on an idea taken from the Dawn of the Dead remake - Twitchers are Zombies that have not had their brains totally traumatized. This results in any undead damaged in this way still having the ability to move around, albeit in a sporadic, uncontrollable state.

Expands:

Zombie Plague
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Horror, Miniatures, Zombies

name: The Legacy of Kings
description:
The Legacy of Kings was a boardgame set in the AD&D Birthright world. It was played at conventions in the late 1990s. In 2000 it was made available for download from the Wizards of the Coast website.

The game covers the grand strategic conflict for the continent of Cerilia. One player is the game moderator and also controls the Awnsheglien. The other players act as regents of the various realms.

name: The Glasgow Game
description:
THE GLASGOW GAME is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case the City of GLASGOW in the Heart of Scotland. The YMCA there is famous for its large hostel, housing some 400 young men.

This game is distinctly different from the other Ricken/Triaktiv games being predominantly Black in colour where the norm is a green or plum colour. See the pictures for greater detail of this.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Aventura na Selva
description:
In this game, one player is the explorer, who needs to find the treasure in the jungle, the other player is the guardian of the treasure, who places traps and hides the treasure.

There are cards that let the explorer pass the traps without losing one of his time counters.

If the explorer loses all of his time counters, the guardian wins the game, but if the explorer finds the treasure, he wins the game.

name: Durchs Gartenjahr
description:
This games simulates one year gardening: You start in January and roll your pawn through the seasons.
You also draw cards with crops and flowers. If you are in the right month you can plant or harvest them
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Naughty Dogs
description:
"As the clothes go out to dry in the sun, naughty dogs steal them... just for fun!"

Naughty Dogs is a children's game for two to four players, ages four and up. The game consists of a clockwork powered clothes line that rotates and four dogs that leap up when a paddle is pressed (or hit). The four colors are red, blue, green and yellow.

To set up, you attach 12 articles of clothing to the washing line, three of each color of pants, shirt and socks (in increasing order of difficulty), wind up the mechanism and let it go. The clothes line spins and the players hit the paddles to make their dog leap up to grab the clothing.

The winner of the game is the person the highest score. you get 10 points for pants, 15 for the tee-shirt and 20 for the socks in your color. Each article of clothing your dog gets that isn't in your color costs you 30 points, so it pays to be a bit careful.

A warning to parents... This is quite a noisy game to play, but each game only lasts for about two minutes.
publishers: Chad Valley Co Ltd., Crown & Andrews Ltd., New Entertainment Ltd, Nilco S.A., Popular de Juguetes, Premier Classic, Spear's Games

name: The RIKEN Center for Developmental Biology Card Game
description:
The RIKEN Center for Developmental Biology has created a set of game cards illustrating basic concepts, such as embryonic stages of development, cell types, various model organisms used in research, and mutations in the fruit fly Drosophila.

Printed versions of these cards have been distributed to visitors to the CDB Open House as well as at a number of international academic meetings. The data for the cards are now available free of charge for non-commercial use.

http://www.cdb.riken.jp/en/index.html -- Go to 'Learning Center', then 'Multimedia' to download the game.
publishers: The RIKEN Center for Developmental Biology

name: Combiletra
description: Combiletra (Combi-letter) is a word game from Sonata. Players shuffle hexagonal letter-tiles, draw them one by one and try to form words.

name: PSL Guide to Wargaming
description:
This introduction to miniature wargaming includes an introduction and articles by eight different authors on wargaming 10 different historical periods. At the end of each chapter, Quarrie presents rules for that particular period.

The historical periods covered include the following: Ancients, Medieval, Renaissance/17th century, 18th century, Napoleonic, Crimean war, American Civil/Franco-Prussian wars, Colonial warfare, World War I, and World War II.
categories: American Civil War, Ancient, Book, Civil War, Medieval, Miniatures, Modern Warfare, Napoleonic, Post-Napoleonic, Renaissance, Wargame, World War I, World War II

name: Octopus
description: Players are divided into teams of two. Each player dons head, wrist, and ankle Velcro™ straps. A team starts the game standing. The JUMBO cube is then rolled twice and the team then connects the appropriate Velcro™ straps according to the colors rolled on the JUMBO cube. Play continues until a team wins the game by being the first to complete 25 connections.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Know the Stars and Planets
description:
MB #4028. For the budding astronomer of 1960. Ages 8 to 12. This game has two game boards, "Know the Stars" and "Know the Planets". Each comes with a deck of 24 card printed with some astronomy trivia. The mechanics are similar to Trivial Pursuit. One player draws a card and asks the opponent a trivia question from it. A correct answer allows the player to put a mark in a tic-tac-toe box on the game board. For each completed row or column on the game board the player scores its point value. As each of the 9 squares on the tic-tac-toe board has a different value, there is some strategy here. Correct answers to 6 of the 24 cards enable a choice to mark a tic-tac-toe square or to erase an opponents mark. A simple plastic cover allows write-on/wipe off.
The gameboard and card can also be used for a much simpler form of tic-tac-toe for the younger players.

name: Elemental Chess
description:
Do you like to play chess and enjoy fantasy card games like Magic the Gathering? Then you will probably like Elemental Chess. It is based on classic chess rules but includes a twist of fantasy.

Instead of a full complement of chess pieces, each player begins the game with five pawns, two rooks, two knights, and an elementalist.

The elementalist moves like a king and is capable of casting spells from a deck of 32 cards. The spells are used to summon creatures from the various elements: earth, air, water, or fire.

Each turn a player will move an existing chess piece or cast a spell. The object of the game is to put your opponent's elementalist in checkmate.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Grid Movement, Memory

name: Krizovky
description: Each player starts with a certain number of puzzle pieces with has printed on them capital letters and a small number (value). Each player makes a word in his/her turn and counts the value of the word and adds it to the players total value. It is like scrabble but there is no board to play on, so it is very flexible in its area.

name: The Search For The Graf Spee
description:
From the publisher's catalog: "Once again the German pocket-battleship is loose in the South Atlantic and the British player faces the challenge of finding and bringing her to battle. Graf Spee comes complete with die-cut counters, rules booklet, battle board and two movement boards."

Another entry in the long line of AH Bismarck-style search and battle naval wargames, this one is very rare. As the name implies, it covers the search for the German "pocket battleship" Graf Spee in 1939.

With the usual low-quality Third Millenia components (especially the counters) and very simple rules, it is nevertheless a pretty fun game.

Like AH Bismarck, Midway, et al, movement and search are conducted on the two identical map sheets, and battles are resolved on the battle and charts sheet. Turn order is:
a. German player rolls for bad weather (no searches). German player moves.
b. British player searches.
c. British player moves.
d. German player searches.
e. If both in same hex, resolve battle.
f. When all battles are resolved, advance the turn record and start over.

The British can search the hexes ships are in, and one more hex within four hexes (search aircraft). Aircraft carriers (4 British and 1 French) can search the six adjacent hexes. The German player can search the hexes ships are in, plus the Graf Spee has two search aircraft that can search within four hexes. The German player can also search any other three hexes on the board (u-boat reports?).

Both players must keep track of fuel expenditures, and both have supply ships available to re-fuel (or they can re-fuel in ports). Every other turn the German player can roll on a table to sink one (or two) merchantmen. If he sinks any, he then rolls on another table to see how many turns later he must inform the British player in which hex the sinking occurred. The German player must sink a number of merchant ships and escape the map to win; otherwise the British player wins.

No indication is given of map or time scale. I suspect search board turns are one day. 20 turns to a game.

Components: two identical 14" x 24" hex-gridded search map sheets, one 14" x 24" battle and chart sheet, one rule folder (five small pages), plus 119 of 1/2-inch die-cut unit counters.
I think there were 24 actual ship counters, some "?" s and "search" counters, and a bunch of blanks (my copy is unfortunately incomplete).

name: Napoleon's Peninsula Campaign
description: This is the last game from designer Joseph Angiolillo from the trilogy of games about the Napoleonic Wars and features Napoleon's Peninsular Campaign. See both of the other games for a complete description. Those two games are Napoleon's Italian Campaigns and Napoleon's Russian Campaign.

name: Get a Letter
description:
Get a Letter is a spectacular letter game in which creativity and spelling go hand in hand. The tiles overlay to form letters. Line up the tiles to create a word.

Create a word using as many tiles as possible.

When a player is finished, the number of tiles they have left are counted and become that player's penalty points. The winner is the player who finishes the game with the least number of penalty points.

Home Page: http://www.recenttoys.com/index.php?id=19

name: Change
description:
A tactical game with black and white wooden chips players try to collect.

In the beginning, in front of each player lies as a row of mixed up black and white chips. According to different "formulas" printed on cards, players may trade a row of chips (e.g. black-white-white-black) for a different set (e.g. black-black-black). When a formula card is used it is discarded and a new one is drawn.
Making skillful use of the "currency" allows players to change chips as long as they end up having collected chips of only one color - they win!

name: Fische fangen
description: A pond is filled with different types of fish. Dice rolls determine which type of fish is caught. Winner is the one who catches the most fish.

name: Liar's Poker
description:
An implementation of a dice bluffing game, similar to Liar's Dice. A player, the "Declarer" rolls the dice and announces what poker hand is under the cup. The player to the left, the "Caller", announces whether he or she believes the Declarer. If the Caller believes the Declarer then the Caller takes the cups and is the new declarer, and must declare a higher poker hand from the dice under the cups, with the player to the left as the new Caller. Play continues until a Caller accuses the Declarer of being a liar, and the dice are revealed. If the Declarer was lying then the declarer must pay out, but if the Declarer was telling the truth, the Declarer collects from the other players.

The rules as printed don't give a lot of detail about the game. Though money is provided, it's not made clear how bets take place, nor what the game ending conditions are. Presumably, like Liar's Dice, the game would end when one player has all of the money, and players would be eliminated when they have no money.

Unlike Liar's Dice, only one player is rolling at one time, and there are a total of five dice that are rolled.

name: Monopoly: Turkish or Istanbul
description: This is simply the Turkish version of Monopoly. It is essentially the same as the standard Monopoly game and other variations, but in Turkish with the properties all being places in Istanbul. In the current version, two of the railroads are replaced with ferry terminals. The chance and community chest cards are apparently based on the British version and thus lack pictures aside from an arrow for advancing to Go and bars for going to jail. They also differ slightly from the modern American cards and are closer to the older American version.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Symbotica
description:
The game is based around placing symbol cards so that either their colour or shape match their neighbours. The game area is restricted to an 8 by 8 card limit.

Symbotica can be played in four different ways: the Standard Game, the Simple Game, Five Card Symbotica and the one player Symbotica Challenge.

The aim of the Standard, Simple and Five Card Symbotica games is to score the maximum number of points. Points are scored based on the placing of the cards. In order to cater for different age groups, the scoring is either based on addition or multiplication.

The one player Symbotica Challenge consists of trying to get as close as possible to the full grid of 64 cards using the same placement rules as the other games but without any scoring.

The game appeals to a wide range of ages from children learning simple pattern matching, addition or multiplication right up to those adults who want to keep their mind fit.

Home Page: http://www.symbotica.com/

name: Admiralty: Fighting Sail Warfare – 1750-1815
description:
Admiralty is a set of Wargame rules for fighting under sail for the period 1750 - 1815.

It is a rules-set ( 20+ pages ) and does not contain any figures. It's design in relatively simple and designed to allow players field large forces and still maintain realism in their simulations.
categories: Age of Reason, Miniatures, Napoleonic, Nautical, Wargame
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Measurement Movement, Paper-and-Pencil, Simulation

name: Ant Farm Game
description: Board game simulating an ant farm as player use tweezers to move the small lifelike plastic ants throughout the underground colony.
mechanics: Memory, Race, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Great American Puzzle Factory, Uncle Milton

name: Cthulhu Skirmish
description:
Board & card game for 2 players. Battle between two factions in the Lovecraft Universe. Abstract skirmish level combat. Each figure represents a single man/creature (unit). There are 8 Factions:
Human Investigators
Deep Ones
Humanoids
Yithians
Elder Things
Mi-Go
Serpent People
Cultists

name: WordSpot Jr.
description:
From the publisher:

The object of WordSpot Jr. is simple: find hidden words among the lettered tiles and mark them using WordSpot tokens. Words may go up, down, across, backwards or diagonally. The first player to use all his or her tokens wins! It's a fun and easy way to help children develop their reading and spelling skills while challenging adults, too. Contains 28 letter tiles and 55 marking tokens.

name: Monopoly: Grand Rapids Edition
description:
This is the Grand Rapids, Michigan edition of Monopoloy producted by USAopoly. Here is an article on the students from Grand Valley State University who helped develop the game.

http://www.youngmoney.com/entrepreneur/student_entrepreneurs...

The following is from a GVSU press release.

Grand Rapids Monopoly to raise scholarshp money

A student organization at Grand Valley State University's Seidman College of Business has created a Grand Rapids themed version of the board game Monopoly. Soon players will be able to buy companies like Alticor, Meijer and Steelcase while moving pieces shaped like local landmarks like Calder's La Grande Vitesse.

The project was spearheaded by the Collegiate Entrepreneurs' Organization (CEO) at Grand Valley. Business sponsorships and sales of the game will raise funds to establish a CEO student scholarship at Grand Valley.
The game board is patterned after the familiar Monopoly board, but it features prominent local businesses in the place of the original names. Boardwalk is Alticor, Park Place is Meijer, and Steelcase is Pacific Avenue (the three highest valued properties in the game). Other featured businesses are Behler-Young, Louis Padnos Iron and Metal Company, The Gilmore Collection, 1913 Room, Rockford Construction, Old Orchard, WZZM, Grand Valley State, Calvin College, and Aquinas College. The hotels will be shaped as the Amway Grand, and houses will represent the conservatory at the Frederick Meijer Gardens. Tokens will also be shaped as local attractions, such as the La Grande Vitesse, Leonardo Da Vinci Horse, John Ball statue, and other area landmarks.

Full text availalble here:
http://www.gvsu.edu/forms/ceo/Media/monopoly2.pdf

Another article on the project may be found here:
http://www.gvsu.edu/successstory/index.cfm?fuseaction=home.s...;id=FA32E53B-E926-4249-DCBD5FC17644C204
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: 11 de Setembre
description:
[EN] 11 de Setembre is an introductory wargame with very simple rules, reproducing the siege and fall of the city of Barcelona on September 11th 1714, at the hands of the Spanish-French Bourbon army. The fall of Barcelona effectively ended the War of the Spanish Succession.

It contains one 50x70 cm map, a rulebook and 88 counters.


[CA] 11 de Setembre és un wargame introductori amb regles molt simples i que reprodueix el setge i caiguda de Barcelona l'11 de setembre de 1714 a mans de l'exèrcit borbònic francoespanyol. La caiguda de Barcelona posà fi a la Guerra de Successió Espanyola.

El joc conté un mapa de 50x70 cm, un llibret de regles i 88 fitxes.


[ES] 11 de Setembre es un wargame introductorio con reglas muy simples y que reproduce el asedio y caída de Barcelona el 11 de setiembre de 1714 a manos del ejército borbónico franco-español. La caída de Barcelona puso fin a la Guerra de Sucesión Española.

El juego contiene un mapa de 50x70 cm, un libro de reglas y 88 fichas.

name: Manchester
description:
A chess variant in which spaces have a card with a picture of a chess piece drawn on it which determines the move of the player's pawns. It is played on a 6 by 6 grid; to start with only the end zones have cards on them, but each turn another (face up from a stack)is placed onto an empty space. Pawns starting from spaces without cards can only move forward or backwards and can't capture.

The game is thus partly about conventional chess and partly about constructing the board to favour yourself.

My copy was sold as a double game with Thataway, with which it shares a board and some pieces; I don't know if it has ever been sold separately.

I believe this game was originally sold as Chafts, as early as 1986. David Watts visited Cardiff to trial it.

name: Crok Crok Crok
description:
Website says:
A game combining response and memorization skills, Crok Crok Crok is an amusing introduction to the eating habits of familiar animals. Five animals and a little boy are sitting down to eat. On the dinner table, we have an apple, egg, carrot, banana and snow peas. Roll the die to determine who eats first. We see its the monkey. Quick -- a player must grab the foods that are part of the animal's regular diet to earn food token chip. The game ends when one (or all) players collect all five food tokens.

A one-of-a-kind treasure containing 6 wooden food toys, 30 round chips, wooden die, guide card, and set of game rules. Made from recycled materials and wood with PEFC label guaranteeing sustainable forest management practices. Crok...Crok...Crok - it's the funny sound of chewing!
publishers: Bioviva, Kvale Good Natured Games, LLC

name: Monopoly: Los Angeles Lakers
description: Special-edition Monopoly board features famous Lakers players throughout history. Also contains six collectible Lakers-themed pewter tokens, including: Lakers Logo, Basketball Hoop, NBA Basketball, NBA Championship Trophy, Defensive Player and Offensive Player.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Szaleńczy wyścig
description:
The background story (from the box) of the game is set in the first half of XXI century when a new type of car race are arranged. The competitors drive an armored and armed cars and the main rule of the race is that the winner takes all.

"Szalenczy Wyscig" ("The Mad Race") simulates car race taking into account different road surface (ice, cinder, tarmac), car equipment (including different types of tires, armor, weapon, engines). The track is build with modular board and it is possible to make 8 different tracks. The players decide what is track surface - it can vary along the way - and they can place in some additional obstacles like ditches or oil splodges.

Game mechanics is based on secret planning the car movement for a game round. The players are using the special "car sheets" and reveal their movement simultaneously. They can not only plan the movement but also they can use weapons. If the cars are on the same field depending on their speed and planned movement type they can hit each other or avoid collision.

After the race the players get their prices depending on their place. With money prices they can repair and upgrade cars buying additional equipment. The winner is chosen after several races.

name: Monopoly: Bayreuth
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Bayreuth, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Essen
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of Essen, in Germany.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Suite Life Double the Fun Card Game
description: Turn up cards for points until you decide to stop and you keep your points for that turn. If you keep going, you wager the amount of points you have accumulated and push your luck to gain more with each card you turn up. If you turn up a Moseby, you lose all the points you gained for that turn, UNLESS you get a Joker Zack, which makes you immune to Moseby. Collect pairs of Zack and Cody cards for extra points. The player with the most points when the cards run out is the winner.
categories: Card Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Tempo
description:
From the cover: "Get set! You're about to begin the fastest card game in the world"

The Dealer shuffles one pack of 55 cards and deals 11 face down to each player.
Player don't take turns in this games: everyone plays together and can make a move whenever they want.
The moves are:

1. Discarding a card: the cards you discard are spread out - face up
2. Drawing a card: you can choose any card on the table or you can take the first card of the pack.

name: Cadbury's Milk Tray Man In Black Game
description:
From the box cover:

"Cadbury's Milk Tray MAN IN BLACK Game - an exciting and sophisticated game of skill, nerve and strategy for 2-4 players.

Players become the mysterious 'Man In Black' and:
- encounter landslides, avalanches and floods
- block your opponents and deliver the box of Milk Tray
- make incredible get-aways by car or helicopter

The game was produced by Waddington's games in the UK as a promotional item for Cadbury's "Milk Tray" chocolates. The advertising campaign for Milk Tray featured arguably the most famous advertising character in British TV history, the Milk Tray Man, a pseudo James Bond character who performed several death defying feats in order to deliver a box of chocolates.

Game contents:
- 1 plastic playing area, in two parts
- 76 hexagonal route tiles
- 4 "Men In Black" playing pieces
- 4 helicopters
- 4 getaway cars
- 6 getaway route tiles (double sided)
- 4 landslide markers
- 4 tree markers
- 1 "Man In Black" trump tile
- 1 "Lady" tile
- 1 "Start" tile
- dice and shaker

The object of the game is for each player to race their individual "Man In Black" piece from the Start hexagon tile, across the playing area, and to the Lady hexagon tile.

Each player is dealt 5 route tiles, a "Man In Black" playing piece, a getaway car piece and a helicopter piece.

On their turn, each player has the choice of either placing a Route tile on the board, or throwing a dice to see how many squares they can move their piece along already placed Route tiles.

Each route tile features a different road segment marked with squares. Some squares feature hazards which delay the player. Route tiles can be placed in any position, at any time throughout the game, on each players turn.

The getaway car, helicopter, landslide and tree markers can be used to move the players piece further, or to obstruct other players.

Game components consist of quality heavy duty card tiles, a moulded plastic board, and hand painted pieces.

The game is notable for being one of the earliest examples of a tile laying game, with each game producing a new road layout for players to travel.
categories: Adventure, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Spies/Secret Agents

name: Wizards School
description:
"Players are young apprentices at their first semester of Wizards school."

"There are 6 fields of study that adepts accumulate lesson points in: Divination, Conjuration, Alchemy, Transformation, Invocation, and Extra Curricular Activities."

"The semester lasts 17 weeks. The game ends at the end of turn 17."

"The player who, at the end of the game, has accumulated the most lesson points in the most Fields of Study is the winner. If there is a tie, then the tied player with the most lesson points wins."

name: Polar Quizz
description:
Polar Quizz is trivia-type game about the polar environment, both arctic and antarctic: fauna, polar explorers, geography, indigenous people, etc.

No particular knowledge on the subject is required to play. Players just need to use their memory, as the facts are given along the game. Thus, kids can easily win against adults, and learn valuable information at the same time.

The game is made of 100 square cards. Each card displays the picture of an animal, a polar explorer, a map, etc... All the questions and answers are gathered in a booklet. Each card has a number referring to a set of questions and their answers in the booklet. This feature allows the games to be easily translated in many different languages. Currently, each box contains 4 languages: English, French, German and Norwegian.

Players try to win cards by answering their questions. Each card yields points and the winner is the first to score 7 points. If a player gives the wrong answers to a card, the right answers are given to all the participants. Hence, later in the game, this card becomes easier to be won, but only if you could memorize these answers.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Memory, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Renegade Nuns on Wheels
description:
A spin-off of Macho Women With Guns, introduces vehicles and nuns.

Macho Women with Guns is a humorous tactical miniatures game with some RPG elements tacked on for good measure. Players take on the roles of heavily armed women battling everything from Drunken Frat Boys to Bthulhu and more. One player controls the monsters and NPCs while the rest play the women. Characters are created with a point based system governing the stats of Strength, Dexterity, Macho, Looks, and Health. (There is no Intelligence score), as well as various skills like "Run in High Heels" and "Hit Things With Things"...
Combat and skill use is based on a 3d6 roll system combined with double-sided cut-out paper miniatures (cardboard bimbos), and hex boards supplied with the game. Gameplay is quick, easy to learn, and often very absurd.

Integrates with:

Macho Women With Guns
categories: Fighting, Humor, Mature / Adult, Miniatures, Religious
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Line of Sight, Modular Board, Paper-and-Pencil, Player Judge, Role Playing, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Variable Player Powers, Variable Set-up

name: Giro d'Italia Ciclo-Automobilistico
description: Double purposed Italian game from Milan published in the '60s. A simple roll and move game played with bikes or cars on the same track (Giro d'Italia). A cycling race and a car race can be played on the same board. The cycling game features three teams of two riders (whereas the car race features 6 independent cars) and the race consists of eight stages, including a time-trial. Points are awarded to the first three riders in each stage, but not all the stages award the same number of points.

name: Monopoly: Marseille
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of the city of Marseille, in France.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Montcuq
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements of the city of Montcuq, in France.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Monopoly: Vendée
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

The classic Monopoly with constructions and other elements from the Vendée region, in France.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: BRY
description:
A board game with the strategy of chess and the simplicity of checkers.

Players have 3 colors to choose from: blue, red & yellow (BRY). Each player controls 9 pieces of their color: 3 square pieces, 3 hex pieces and 3 round pieces. Printed on each piece is the shape of the kind of opponents’ piece it can capture: square, hex or round.

Each player has one square piece that can capture opposing square pieces, one square piece that can capture opposing hex pieces and one square piece that can capture opposing round pieces. The same is true for hex pieces and round pieces.

The playing board is triangular shaped with 3 types of sections: 3 Nests (where pieces start the game), 3 Pens (where captured pieces go) and the Ring (a center section where the action takes place).

Pieces start the game in their nest and move directly to any empty space in the ring. They capture opponents’ pieces by moving straight-line to, and replacing, the captured piece in its space. The captured piece is sent to the Pen.

When a piece moves into capture position on an opponent’s piece, prior to capturing it, it can “freeze” the opposing piece by flipping it over. The flipped piece is frozen (cannot move) for one turn.

There a 3 types of normal moves: Nest-to-Ring (described above), swapping a piece from the Pen with a piece in the Ring and moving a piece inside the Ring.

There is one special moved called a “release”, which can occur in a 3-player game if a player is getting “ganged up on” or it can be considered a handicap move for beginning players. It is made by moving a previously captured piece from the Pen back to its nest to return to play.

The winner of the game is the last player to have at least one un-captured piece remaining, after all opponents’ pieces have been captured and placed in their Pen.

The symmetry of the game board combines with a simple game-play routine, creating several layers of strategy with respect to piece positioning and piece selection.

name: Monopoly: Oakland Raiders Collector's Edition
description:
The Raider Nation has invaded America’s favorite board game!

Experience Raiders excitement in and out of the stadium in the Oakland Raiders Collector’s Edition of the MONOPOLY game. Buy, sell and trade the greatest players in Raiders history, including current favorites JaMarcus Russell, Darren McFadden, Ronald Curry, Michael Huff, Kirk Morrison and DeAngelo Hall and retired legends including Jim Otto and Marcus Allen. This collector’s game captures and brings to life the Raiders greatest accomplishments including the team’s Super Bowl championships. Includes six collectible pewter tokens featuring the Raiders helmet, quarterback, linebacker, cheerleader, whistle and football.

Advance to GO and take it to the house with the best of the Oakland Raiders!
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Europa  Reise ohne Grenzen
description:
L'Europe Sans Frontiers is a game of traveling Europe with a trivia question element.

Objective:
be the first to travel to your destination
- moving by turn -
each player has to travel through 5 (different) cities in Europe along a given route
he/she memorizes the route - unknown to others - draws tickets, bonus chips, answers question cards, collect more bonus chips,... in order to move as fast as possible
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Lunch Box Game
description:
From the publisher:

Race to fill your lunch box
Identify healthy food and improve your memory skills as you race to fill your lunch box with tasty items.

name: Box of Spiders
description:
"If you start with a box of spiders, pretty soon you're left with one mean looking spider."

BoS is played with a standard deck of playing cards, including two jokers.

Deal the cards into 6x9 grid; this forms the playing area. Number cards should be dealt face-up. Picture cards and jokers should be dealt face down.

Standard 2 player game:
- Player 1 has the red number cards (red spiders)
- Player 2 has the black number cards (black spiders)
- Court cards and jokers are flies

Each turn consists of a player making a capture:
- The player moves a spider of their colour over any number of friendly pieces and empty spaces onto any fly or an enemy spider of equal or lower value.
- Movement is orthogonal only
- If no capture is posible, the player must pass

When both players pass, the game ends. Players score 1 point for each remaining spider of their colour, and 1 point for each captured card.

3-4 player rules:
Each player gets the number cards in 1 suit. In a 3 player game, there will be a neutral colour of spider. These do not move, but can be captured according to the normal rules.

name: Mappa-Mundi
description:
Produced by Waddingtons in the 1920's.

Two games in one; a jigsaw board of the world, combined with a general knowledge game where players have to correctly identify the locations of capitals of the world. However, the general knowledge part of the game cannot be played until the jigsaw board has been completed.

The jigsaw was 32" x 18", and at the time of production was the largest cardboard jigsaw ever made.

Game contents:

1 map of the world in the form of a 32" x 18" jigsaw
1 paper map of the world (as a reference for the jigsaw)
4 sets of capital city counters (red, blue, green and white)

In the general knowledge part of the game, each player in turn tries to correctly place a capital city on the jigsaw board.

If they correctly place the capital city, they score 4 points.
If they cannot place the capital city, they can put it to one side and score 0 points.
If they incorrectly place the capital city, they lose 2 points.

The winner is the player with the most points.

The game was something of a rarity even when in production; it was expensive, and the general knowledge part of the game was an obvious afterthought. However, it is prized by collectors of vintage jigsaws, and has some curiosity value for the now-obsolete names used for countries on the map - for example Siam, Persia, Arabia and Ceylon. Definitely a remnant of the British Empire ;)

name: Sverige-resan
description: This game is about learning some Swedish geography. The game board features a map of Sweden on which the players move between cities and towns, by road, railroad, sea or plane. Each player starts with 4 randomly selected destination tiles which they may visit in any order. Upon placing a destination tile in the corresponding location, the face-down tile at that destination is drawn. Points are awarded for every destination visited, and province cards may award bonus points if you are lucky. The game ends when a player runs out of destination tiles, and the player with the most points wins.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: 1,2,3: Mäusezählerei
description:
While the cat is sleeping, the mice zips to and from the ladder. How many treats are there?

In this game Haba combines three classic product groups into one game. The games contains three thematically connected games adapted to the age of the children. The game ideas increase in difficulty with age and are a classifying game for 2 year olds, a simple dice game for 3 year olds and a jigsaw-puzzle and searching game for 4 year olds. Each of the games teaches counting to children.
categories: Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Math, Number, Puzzle

name: Tsotsi
description:
Power hungry politicians, bold and brazen criminals and the full arm of the law all come together in this back-stabbing, bullet-flying card game about law and order in South Africa.

Life can be tough in the streets of South Africa for those on the right side of the law. You may be a politician elected into position on the promise of cleaning up the streets. You will need the help of other politicians and the combined forces of the law to rid your region of its 10 major crimes. If you do it before time runs out you win.

For those on the wrong side of the law, life can be equally tough, fighting the law and trying to scratch a living. You may be a criminal seeking to expand your empire on the streets of South Africa. You need to work against the law keepers to keep crime out there before time runs out.

Each player is assigned a secret identity. Either a politician or a criminal. A starting hand of 6 cards is dealt to each player. There are 10 separate crime cards, each with a negative value. Theses are turned over one at a time until solved. Crimes are solved by placing positive cards from your hand on top of the negative crime card until the number reaches 0 or greater. However, their are negative valued cards as well that delay the process and 12 special cards with various functions. The criminals have ample opportunity to delay the process of crime solving.

If the 10 crime cards are solved before all the cards run out, the politicians win. Otherwise, the criminal (or criminals) wins.
mechanics: Cooperative Game, Deduction, Hand Management, Hidden Roles, Negotiation, Take That, Team-Based Game

name: Pinky Li: The Bad Mushroom
description:
Pinky Li - The Bad Mushroom is book 1 in the Pinky Li Series.

It's a "Game 'n a book" you could say.

This book contains all of the following and is aimed at getting small children (4 to 7 years old) to read and play games at the same time!

- "The Great Mushroom Race game"
- An illustrated storybook about the Bad Mushroom.
- A Pinky Li Poster
- A Pinky Li Games and Coloring Book
- A book like box that can be turned into a 3D theatre

This Game in a Book is already available in English and French from the http://www.pinky-li.com website.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Formula 1 World Champion
description: Formula 1 is racing game with changing game board. The game can be played with 2-8 players or with 2-4 teams.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Miam Miam
description: Miam Miam was published in France. In this card game (with 53 cards) each player tries to create sandwiches (for example with ham, cheese, tomatoes, salade) and tries to do so by creating the most valuable sandwiches. There also is a joker card with mayonnaise on it.

name: Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? Entertainment
description:
Manufacturer's Description
A new way of playing the board game based on the popular TV quiz show. The host uses a score pad to plot the progress of the players whilst testing them with questions on all types of Entertainment.

Tension and excitement builds up as the players get closer to the million, and as in the TV show, they can use their lifelines.
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Party Game, Trivia

name: Lesehexe
description:
In Lesehexe, you want to find as many matching word cards as possible. Start by placing a green starter card (A-M) into the card frame, then search for a matching word card. To check whether the cards have been placed together correctly, try to place the witch's shoes into the cutouts. Who can collect the most word cards?

Lesehexe includes seven different game ideas for practicing letters and simple words, providing players with plenty of variety.

name: Operation Sea Lion
description:
Operation Sea Lion is available on the issue nº 49 of the spanish miniatures magazine "Wargames, Soldados y Estrategia".

Its a small wargame that simulates a "what if?" invasion of Great Britain by the German forces in September 1940.
The board is sized as an A4 page (29,7x21 cm) with the counters on another page the same size.

The counters represent mostly Divisions, but a few Brigades and Battalions are also available.
Sea and Air units, as well as other counters (mines, damage, etc) are available as well.

The game is an easy to play and rather simple one, even for its size, with a very simple naval and air phases, and combat mechanics.

The board and counter pages are included in the magazine, and the rules can be downloaded on its site. (see link, below)

name: Italy Awakes
description:
Italy Awakes: The Birth of a Nation 1848-1859

This is a simple and very playable simulation of the Italian Wars for Independence, the First and the Second, with 2 scenarios (1848 and 1859), for
two players, but also playable solitaire without significant problems. It can be completed in under 3 hours of play, with enough beef to interest even
the grognard, but mostly for the newcomers to the hobby.

Each game turn is 10 days of real time and each unit represents around 3/4000 soldiers. In the tradition of our previous effort, Prussia Rising, Italy awakes is more a game than an historical
simulation, but we still think that playing it could be a fun way to learn a little more about such an important period for the history of Italy, Europe
and the world.

Contains:
5 Pages of Rules
63 x 29cm Map (in 3 parts)
395 Counters

name: Ocean Bingo
description: Ocean Bingo is a fairly standard bingo game. The primary difference is that instead of numbers, there are ocean animals on the grid. There is a deck of sea creatures that is shuffled, and cards are drawn and read to players who then put chips on matching animals. Instead of making a single line across the board horizontally, vertically or diagonally, the players want to make the letters S, E or A. The box contains 6 picture boards (bingo cards), 42 animal cards w/ descriptions and chips to cover boxes on the cards.

name: Heads Up!
description:
This is a memory type game with a 3 x 3 board with 9 heads. Each player gets a set of 9 cards representing the 9 heads.

On each turn, everyone except the switcher covers their eyes. The switcher then moves 2 heads around. The players open their eyes and take the cards out of their set they think were switched. If they get both right, they get 2 tokens. One right gets 1 token, and none right gets no tokens. An agreed upon number of tokens wins the game (the rules suggest 5).

name: Haab
description:
The sister game to Junishi, 12 Moons,Neteru, and Zodiakos,
Haab is an abstract strategy game inspired by the Mayan Zodiac. (Each player controls 6 of the 19 signs.)

The object of Haab is to move one of your 6 pieces into your opponent's Gate, which is located at the opposite end of the board, in between your opponent's Spawn Areas.

Players begin at either end of a board comprised of 23 circles.
At the start of the game there are not any pieces on the board. Any pieces that a player wishes to use must be "spawned" in one of the Spawn Circles on that player's side of the board.
Players may move the pieces that they already have on the board either by moving them into adjacent circles or by jumping over friendly pieces.
Players also may use their pieces to capture their opponent's piecess by jumping over them.

Haab is a simple and fast paced abstract strategy game that is easy to learn and usually plays in under 20 minutes. It comes in a little cloth bag that also serves as the game board
and it can be carried in any pocket that is big enough to hold a pack of gum.

Haab is a complete game that can be expanded by combining it with its sister games Junishi, 12 Moons, Zodiakos and Neteru.
(source : the publisher)

name: Gobba: ReElection in Big Gobba
description:
Purple-skinned inhabitants of Gobland settled down wherever their short but nimble legs carried them. However, the heart of the nation beats in the capital of Big Gobba. It's here, on the Hill slopes, where the local chiefs dwelled. Upon discovering on the morrow of the recent festival that city's elite'd got lost somewhere, common goblins gave all other stuff up — it's high time to climb up the very top of the Hill, to the Cauldron, strike it and seize a better office.

Who doesn't want to become the Great Chief and rule the biggest Gobba in the world?! I'm asking you — who?

According to the classification, Gobba is a kind of "resource gathering and winning on points" game. Goblin players travel around the levels of the Hill and do their best to collect the required quantity of resources in order to win election for one of five offices.

Under the Hill a large Dump spreads out — upon getting here, players draw a card from the catch deck. They might get either a gizmo of some value and with some ability or a cataclysm impacting the overall situation in Big Gobba. As goblins are sly by nature, they can even hide a cataclysm that is unfavorable for them. However, when revealed, the deceit will be punished for sure.

The level above the Dump is occupied by Hovels. It's the place where goblins make hidings of their cards, so that their hand can be unloaded. However, it's a risky business, as there might come some enthusiasts for exploring others' hidings.

Yet higher the craftsmen level lies. Each cell up there has its own ability. For instance, in Hurler you can pay for flying to any other cell, in Booth you can play a shell game with another goblin, in Bazaar you can buy or sell a gizmo, and so on.

Above the craftsmen level, the elected elite of Big Gobba dwells. At first the area is empty, still whenever some goblin becomes elected — other players will have to pay for passage through the occupied dwelling.

The Cauldron is situated on the very top of the Hill. To announce an election, you have to climb up there and strike it. Whoever makes a higher bid, wins. Unless, to speak the truth, some evil-minded goblin throws a Sour Watermelon and scuttles the election. I bet they can.

Still, even if you succeeded in getting some office, it's too early to relax. The point is nobody in Big Gobba has ever abolished reelections. They do cost more but cunning competitors can hardly be frightened by a high price.

The victor is the goblin who gets more offices, and if there is an equal number — the goblin with senior offices. For instance, Trader stands higher than the Deputy of Hovels as the elections of the first one are paid with expensive gizmos, and for the Deputy whatever resources go.

During the game goblins can surprise each other in many ways: push down, stab with a knife, befuddle with mushrooms as well as use various sophisticated gizmos like Dusty Sack or Primus Stove.

Goblin-like elections may lead to a triumph or a scuffle but they will never make you weary!

name: Dreck am Stecken
description:
Murder in the night club! Ede K., host of nightly poker games, lies dead in his office. Next to him is a mysterious list, which contains the names of six of the city's most notorious crooks. They are quickly tracked and arrested. But which of them is the murderer? And what crimes have the others committed?

In Dreck am Stecken, slip into the role of one of the crooks and find out what crimes the others have committed so that you may get a more lenient punishment!

name: Dschungel Trio
description:
There are 3x3 field game board and 2 dice for younger players and 4x4 field game board and 3 dice for older players in the game.
The player who has three chips in a row (horizontally, vertically or diagonally) first wins.

In his turn player roll the dice and numbers on the dice may be added together, subtracted, multiplied and divided, so that the result may be used in any free field to place the chip.

for example: There are 1, 3 and 5 dice, so there are many different results.
1+3+5=9
5-3+1=3
3:1+5=8
(3-1)x5=10
etc.
categories: Animals, Children's Game, Dice, Educational, Math, Number

name: Creatures: The Card Game – Chupacabra Promo Cards
description:
Creatures: Chupacabra is a special set of 3 creature cards, available only to Kickstarter backers:


Front: CHU- (11 points)
Middle: -PA- (11 points)
Back: -CABRA (11 points)


These cards are added to the CREATURES deck and can be used like any other creature card during the game.

CHUPACABRA (11) - with glowing red eyes, this mythical creature is purported to drain its victims entirely of blood and will allegedly leave behind a sulfuric stench when alarmed.
mechanics: Campaign / Battle Card Driven, Hand Management, Set Collection

name: Mondo-Carcassonne
description:
Two great games that collide in fun! Mondo-like gameplay, Carcassonne tiles, twenty minutes of fun.

Place your Carcassonne tiles (seventy or so per player) in the middle of the table, face up. Each person has an identical play sheet with spaces to create a map of twenty four tile. Flip a goal card and set the timer. Players start filling their play sheets in real time, no turns, to score points by completing cities and roads, and competing to best satisfy the selected goal.

Solitaire rules included.

name: Greek Salad
description:
Help the chefs prepare a Greek salad! Obey their orders, add veggies and seasonings, mix the ingredients, and the salad is done!

Your goal in Greek Salad is to be the first to get rid of all your cards. Each player starts the game with six cards in hand, then you flip the top card of the deck until a vegetable card is revealed, reshuffling any revealed special cards back into the deck.

On a turn, you can play a vegetable card onto that discard pile as long as your card has at least one more ingredient of a type on the last card played. For example, if the most recently played card has 2 peppers, 4 tomatoes, and 1 piece of feta cheese, the next card played must contain at least 5 tomatoes, at least 3 peppers, or at least 2 pieces of feta cheese.

Alternatively, you can play a special card on a second discard stack. If you play salt, then the next player must play salt themselves or skip their turn and do nothing more than "mix the salad", that is, shuffle the played vegetable cards. If you play a mixing bowl, you flip the vegetable play requirement rule so that played veg cards must have fewer ingredients (but at least one) of a type on the most recently played card; another played mixing bowl cancels this rule. If you play a chef card, you can demand that everyone play vegetable cards that contain a certain ingredient (while following the current more-or-less rule) or you can prohibit an ingredient from being played; this rule lasts until the next special card is played.

If you can't play a card, you must draw a card. Keep taking turns around the table until someone plays their final card — which must be a vegetable card — and goes out, winning the game.

name: Tumblewood
description:
Tumblewood - A Game of Dexterity, Engineering, Strategy, and Fun

Tumblewood is 55 pieces of hand-split white birch. Each piece is 4.75 inches long, yet every piece is unique in shape because it is split with a mallet and wedge in Maine USA rather than being sawed perfectly the same, by the zillions, in China.
It is the unique shape created by this lovingly hand crafted production, and the random tapers and twists of each piece, that makes Tumblewood both beautiful to look at and hold, and more challenging to play. Each game requires a new approach, based on the pieces you have chosen to play. Stacking can go up high, or outward with counter balances and cantilevered sticks. The game can be played solo or with up to 8 or more players. It can be a co-operative game, where all try to work together to build a structure, or a competitive game, where each player tries to place a piece in such a way that it stays on the stack but make the next play more difficult. Tumblewood, in a hand made wooden box is a game that you will want to leave out to be seen and played by anyone who comes to visit. In fact, a pencil is included so that players can sign and date one of the pieces after playing. This creates a living game that becomes a record of gatherings and good fun.

Tumblewood Rules:

Place two relatively matched pieces parallel on top of the Tumblewood box, then begin to build up.
Every piece above the foundation must touch at least two other pieces.
There is no wrong way to play. Go for tallest, widest, most compact, most creative.
Pieces may be divided equally, drawn out one at a time, or each player's piece chosen for them by the next player in rotation. Tumblewood is a creative game. Let your rules be a part of that creativity.


Additional ways to play Tumblewood:

Sabotage
Speed of Height
Leaning Tower
On The Radio
Trestle Bridge
Low Rider


Hand carved "Tumblewood Guardians" and hand carved wooden Gaming Pieces and Score Markers now available.

name: Alchemist Atlier
description:
User summary

A home-made Japanese board game. Players are alchemists, and take turns collecting various resources from different areas of the board; certain more dangerous but more rewarding, and others safe but rather cheap. These are then used to create various objects which gain points. Players can also hire assistants to help out and raise their stats so that materials from more dangerous areas can be collected.

Comes with mounted board, cards, wooden cubes, paper money and dice.

name: Build-up
description:
Build-up is a board game for 2-6 people, each playing the role of a property developer, needing to complete 3 phases of property development - design, construction and marketing.

The winner is the first player to occupy the central Build up square with a ten story building - a stack of ten tiles. The players must also have a Tenant and a Topping Out card and the building must not have any mortgaged stories.

Play is on a game board with dice to move around and select various cards and/or pay/receive money etc. You also get to pick up your essential develop cards like planning permission. You get to travel in/out the board as well as clockwise around each layer (there are three).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Open Drafting, Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Tile Placement, Trading

name: Das Wissensduell: Rund um die Erde
description:
This is a trivia game with questions around the world.
The game includes 100 cards with 100 Questions and answers (on the back side) and four clips in four colours used as player markers.

Players have to estimate facts for questions. There are always 10 different possible answers. There is a clip for each player to mark their answers on the card. Each spot with an answer can only be taken by one player. When all players made their estimations the card is flipped to the backside with the answer. The player with the correct answer or is closest to it gets the card. If theres a tie the next question/card is worth two cards (the old tied card and the next new card).
The first player with 7 cards is the winner.

name: Dotzee
description: From the catalog: Dotzee is a swiftly changing game of pattern recognition which blends luck and strategy into a fun and engaging multiplayer game. Easy and quick to learn, players roll dice and strategically slide them into scoring combinations in order to win. These familiar combinations include four of a kind, two pair, small straight and flush (all of the same color). Each combination created during a turn earns one point. The first player to earn ten points wins the game.

name: Diagonal Blocks
description:
Diagonal Blocks is an abstract strategy game modeled after Blokus, and playable with a Blokus set. The pieces, (same as Blokus) consist of a complete set of all polyominoes up to size 5. The board is 20x20 (smaller in 2 or 3 player variants) with the six squares nearest each corner removed. Play begins at a starting square for each player, and each players subsequent move must contact his previously placed pieces only at a diagonal points. The game ends when no further pieces can be played. The winner is the player who covered the most squares with his pieces.

Vis-a-vis Blokus, the differences are:
(1) The corners are removed from the board so there are barely more squares on the board than pieces to be played.
(2) There are no special scoring bonuses. The count of squares covered is the entire score.
(3) In two player variants, A "swap" rule applies to the second move. This removes the first player advantage.

Variations:
Diagonal Blocks (3 player, intermediate size board)
Diagonal Blocks Duo (2 player)
Diagonal Blocks Classic (2 player, 4 color)

Online Play

Boardspace.net real-time, AI option


Mobile Apps

Boardspace.net local multiplayer or online, IOS
Boardspace.net local multiplayer or online, Android

name: You'll Never Guess!
description: YOU'LL NEVER GUESS! (...or will you?) Stimulate your brain, challenge your skills of deduction, and have fun trying to guess what players are up to! Say the Presenter reads out a question like ‘Where Am I?’. It could be Dallas, France, Hawaii or somewhere else. So how will you figure out where they’re pretending to be? By asking them your own questions to narrow down the possibilities. You could ask: ‘Would I take a plane to get there?’, ‘Is it a city?’, ‘Does it have cold winters?’, or anything else you can think of. You decide what to ask. You may also get to roll for a Letter Clue. In another round you might be asked to guess what someone's supposed to be ‘wearing’, ‘eating’, ‘holding’, and much more.

name: 80's Music Trivia
description:
Presented in a mini collectable 1980’s style boom box, this retro quiz will take you back to the golden days of music. Includes questions from artists such as Michael Jackson, Queen, Run DMC, Bon Jovi, Madonna, Elton Johm, Prince, Bruce Springsteen, Iron Maiden and many more!

Ask the question and the player who answers correctly first gets the card as a point. There are also 3 variants on some cards.

Player with the most cards at the end is the winner.

name: Quadro Color
description:
Players act simutanously and take and try to match the colored tiles from the middle of the table on their boards.

Who was able to place first all correct tiles on his board is the winner.

name: Arcane Legions: Siege Engines of Rome
description:
From the box:

The Romans spent centuries perfecting the science of war, and the Night of Mists only provided them with newer, deadlier ways to control the battlefield. Now you can control Rome's latest technological advance the Steam Ballista. Designed with the help of reclusive dvergar engineers, this massive artillery piece uses magic to heat water and channel steam to propel explosive stones or bolts the size of tree trunks into the enemy ranks with deadly precision.

These lumbering weapons are fielded one to a formation base but are operated by everyday soldiers from your army packs choose between two different unit cards for each ballista to find just the right way to show the enemies of Rome what it means to face the wrath of the Empire.
categories: Ancient, Collectible Components, Dice, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Miniatures, Mythology

name: Sòcc'mel
description:
A trick-taking card game focusing on expressions from Bologna's dialect. Players try to avoid taking suits of unlucky events going around the table by either adding a more powerful event of the same sphere, or trumping the suit with an event of a different sphere (the three spheres being home, work or street). If not avoidable, the trick taking can be mitigated by playing a swear word card, or by a Socc'mel card, which transfer the suit to another player. Goal of the game is pushing the other players anger-meter ("incazzometro") beyond 10 to eliminate them from the game.

The game is marketed for ages 6 up, with the explicit proviso that obscenities from Bologna are widely accepted and not considered offensive (which is the case, to some extent...).

name: DrunkQuest: Dealer Chip
description:
From the Kickstarter campaign:

This chip gets passed to the player who draws the Monster, and stays with that player even if the Monster is moved. When the circle closes the player who drew the Monster may choose to flip the chip. If it lands on Red, 5 drinks are added to the Monster, on Green 5 are removed. This can affect the Monster whether it's been moved or not!
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fantasy, Humor, Party Game

name: БЕРСЕРКнаПОЛЕя (Berserk-opoly)
description: A monopoly-like game in the entourage of a fantasy collectible card game "Berserk". In addition to the standard property acquisition and collecting payment from opponents, players can fight monsters and develop their characters. Getting on certain cells of the field, players can start a battle with monsters and get treasures, which will improve their fighting skills. The measure of fighting abilities is the level. Clashes between players are also possible: 2 players need just to be on the same sector. A mechanism of a fight is simple: the opponents roll a D6, add the number to their level value (that can be improved with artifacts) and the highest sum is the winner! In case of a defeat players don't die. The worst that can happen is the loss of a certain amount of money. Most powerful artifacts the player can receive for the victory over the dragon help you to make your rivals go broke, but do not play a critical role: if someone is doing bad he goes bankrupt anyway and prosperous player can afford to lose a couple of hundred.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Monster Schreck
description:
The players are monsters and have to escape from the monster hunters. This is achieved by elimination: Every monster which gathers 7 or more hunter points is out of the game. Last monster standing is the winner.
Each player has a monster card and draws two action cards into his/her hands, then three hunter cards which are placed openly in front of him/her. Now each player can play action cards on two of the hunters and the monster card can attack the third one. Some action cards can take hunters out of the game while others can redirect them to other players (there is no defense against this). When all actions are resolved, the player with most hunter points has to keep the highest hunter card. When after a few rounds the number of hunter points a player has gathered exceeds 7, that player is out. The others continue untili only one monster is left.

name: Recon Strategy
description:
The object of Recon Strategy is to completely eliminate the opposing players squadrons of fighters. The game consists of a game board divided into two sections by a boundary line straight down the middle, twelve fighter planes, four recon planes, sixteen hit or miss air defense tokens, four different colored dice and four separate sets of cards with twenty- five cards in each set.
The dice are color coded for each squadron. When red and black squadrons move, the amount moved is determined by rolling the black and red dice together. When green and blue squadrons move, green and blue dice are rolled. The number appearing on each die must be moved by that color squadron, whether it is a fighter or a recon plane. No two planes of the same color may be moved in the same turn.

When a fighter has been shot down or destroyed on the ground, the victorious plane receives an ace sticker, to be placed by the victorious plane. Should the winning plane lands safely on its home base, the entire squadron then attains single ace status. The ace sticker is then placed in the corner of the home base's name square. Triple ace status is the highest. In the game you have Recons that destroy fighters on the ground, force fighters to scramble, and expose openings in the air defenses. The game has speed lanes which enable diagonal movement. Otherwise movement is restricted to horizontal or vertical directions.
mechanics: Hand Management, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Trivial Pursuit: TV Edition – Card Set
description:
Card set for use with the Trivial Pursuit: TV Edition – Master Game.


Each player has a circular playing piece with six pie-shaped holes. The goal of the game is to collect a pie in each color. The colors correspond to different question categories.

The board consists of a circular track with spaces in seven different colors. Six of the colors correspond to question categories while the last color gives a new dice roll. Six spaces along the track are "pie spaces", and from these there are "spokes" of track leading to the middle of the board.

Players roll a die and move along the track in any direction they like. When a player stops on a color they get a question of the appropriate category. If the player answers a question correctly while on a pie space, they get a pie of that color (assuming they don't already have it). A correct answer on another square allows the player to roll again.

Once the player has one pie in each color, she can move along the spokes to the middle of the board to win the game.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Konito? Musik
description:
The music edition of Konito?. Complete the fill-in-the-blank statements on the game cards in order to move forward on the modular scoring board. (The length of the game is determined by how many sections are used to create the board.) There is a time limit to complete each card.

The object is to be the first to complete famous song titles and lyrics, or try to make your teammates find the right answer by any possible means.

name: RARRR!! Bonus Cards
description:
In RARRR!!, players first draft monster power cards in order to build their perfect monster, then draft power bid cards to fuel their monsters' rampages through cities. Cities are destroyed using a bidding system, and players are limited in their bids by the amount of each type of power that their monster possesses.

Will you build a super fire-spewing dragon monster, or a more balanced monster that can flatten cities time and time again for the long haul? Either way, it's not a good day to live in the metropolis.

This set of 12 bonus cards was included with the 2014 Kickstarter edition. It includes 4 new monsters and 8 new cities.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Hand Management, Open Drafting, Set Collection

name: Dust Warfare: Operation Babylon
description:
The battle for the craddle of civilization, 1947.

April 1947. When the Blutkreuz Korps unearthed records of an ancient alien energy source hidden in Mesopotamia, they started working on plans to recover it. Now their plans are coming to fruition.

Operation Babylon thrusts the Neue Deutches Afrikakorps (NDAK), the New German Africa Corps, into Allied territory in central Iraq. Opposing them are the elite 4th Marine Division of the United States Marine Corps and the Spetsnaz special forces of the Sino-Soviet Union (SSU) raid both sides, intent on setting the region ablaze.

Operation Bablyon is a campaign book for Dust Warfare. It contains Platoon lists and cards for all three factions.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Miniatures, Science Fiction, World War II
mechanics: Action Points, Dice Rolling, Variable Player Powers

name: Wordious
description:
From the publisher's website:

Challenge friends and family in a exciting letter game with a strategic twist. You build the board – but be smart every tile and board is worth points. If you win you become Wordious!

Spent time playing word puzzle games? Feel it is time for a change? Well meet Wordious… The new word puzzle game with an element of surprise. Wordious is like nothing you have ever seen before, what will happen when you need to place your letters on a gameboard that is made up by tiles, tiles that you and your opponents take turns placing.
Wordious is a family game with classic board game elements.


Each player draws seven letter tiles. Then the board tiles are divided among the players.
At the beginning of a player's turn, they can choose to place a board tile. Each board tile is printed double-sided. If a player decided to place a board tile, they have to play a word on that tile and link it to a word on.
After the player has placed a word, they draw as many letters as played.
The game ends when a player has no letters left or everyone passes.
Every unplayed board tile is worth 15 points at the end of the game. Unplayed letters are penalized.


This game is like a modular Scrabble game.

name: Fliegende Zeilen
description:
In Fliegende Zeilen, players have to create new texts (e.g. a poem or commercial slogan), based on lines from famous poetry.

First, the type of text is picked, than the quote for inspiration is determined randomly. In a limited timeframe, players compete to produce the wittiest text, awarding points to the creations of the others. Highest total wins.

name: Wren's Nest
description: Wren's Nest is a Colors & Counting micro-game (18 cards) for 2-4 players. Each Nest Card contains 4 distinct colors (Red, Yellow, Green, and Blue) with a varying number of points assigned to each color. Players "build" a 4-card nest using one side of each card.
