Your HQ is located in a safe place near Ancedale. In this base of operations, you will create the cure by validating various objectives, prepare your expeditions but also spend your money and experience points on permanent improvements.

In Ancedale's Hope, expeditions are at the heart of the game. But beware, your time is limited, you only have 10 days to find resources, complete the various objectives and finally evacuate the island before the virus infects you too.

An expedition consists of 3 steps:


First: roll the single colored dice to find out the position of arrival on the island. Then roll 2x all 4 dice of the same color to determine the strength of the island's watchtowers
How a day unfolds: At the beginning of each day, during your expedition, roll all 5 dice. The single colored dice will determine the direction of the watchtower's view. The 4 dice of the same color will be used for your movements and for the items collected during that day. Simply note your movement on the map and mark the areas you have searched. At the end of the day you should have enough resources (food and water). In some cases you will also need to find a warm place to shelter from the cold before nightfall. If not, your health will be diminished.
At the end of an expedition: this one can be a real success or an abject failure. Fail and you will lose all the resources collected during the expedition. Succeed and you can bring them back to the safety of your HQ.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Movement Points, Scenario / Mission / Campaign Game, Solo / Solitaire Game

name: Quirrly
description:
There are 65 cards in five colors and with five symbols, numbered 1 to 13. At the start of the game, the players decide whether they will search for symbols or for colors. The task then is to locate all cards with that color/symbol in the right order.

The cards are dealt so that in front of each player, there are two stacks. As soon as the game starts, each player grabs one (any!) stack of cards and looks through it, trying to find the first card he/she needs. When successful, he/she puts the card face-down in front of him/her. Whether successful or not, the rest of the stack is put back to its position. The player then grabs another stack and proceeds. If the players can remember the contents of all the stacks, it's easier for them to find the cards they need later.

The first player to complete his/her stack correctly is the winner. If the fastest player is making a mistake, the player with most correct cards is the winner.

(User summary by HilkMAN)

name: Global Ranking
description:
Players vote for one of three countries that that they think best fits the category showing on the spinner, and are awarded tokens for correct picks. To win the game, players must be the first with 10 tokens.

Global Ranking draws on a player's memory of facts or ability to logically eliminate countries that do not fit the spinner category to increase odds that a guess will be a successful.

Features:
Geography Facts
Demographic Information
Comparisons

name: Tombalo
description:
Tombalo is a balancing game. Together, the players are building a dam from sticks and logs. Each player starts with a supply of sticks and logs.

Each turn, a player will draw a card, which shows how many sticks he may add to the dam. He then has to place these sticks on top of the existing construction (or on top of the starting pillars, if there is nothing yet). If any sticks drop in to the water, the player gets new sticks from the supply.

The first player to get rid of all his sticks wins the game.

name: Adverteasing II
description:
Adverteasing is a trivia game based on product marketing.

The first player takes a question card and asks the next team/player a question. A correct answer is awarded 3 points. If he/she cannot answer inside 15 seconds, anyone else has a chance to answer for 2 points. If there is still no answer, the multiple choice answers on the rear of the card are read and the original guesser has a chance to gain 1 point with a correct answer.

Players who answer questions correctly move up the "career ladder". The first player to make it to 25 points, or President, wins!

name: Defeat in Burma
description:
Game included with Alea Magazine #20.
English rules are available.

From the publishers website,
The Burma campaign, 1942-45. Complete simulation games with 1 rules booklet, historical commentary, 1 DIN A2 map and 120 die cut counters plus some unmounted counters. Game design: Diego Ramírez. Complexity (1-10): 3.
Includes two scenarios: 1942:Japanese occupation and 1945: Allied recapture.

name: Trapdoor Checkers
description: A twist on classic checkers. On each turn players spin to see if they either move, or open and close trap doors. If your checker is on one of the trap doors – look out it might fall through. Adds cunning and luck so that kids and parents have equal chances of winning.

name: Apple Pop
description:
Pop the apple out of the tree. Win by collecting the correct three!

Kids dexterity game.

name: Monopoly: België-Belgique
description:
A monopoly (from Greek monos μόνος (alone or single) + polein πωλεῖν (to sell)) exists when a specific person or enterprise is the only supplier of a particular commodity.

Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

Another version of the classic Monopoly. This time the cases represent different cities in Belgium.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Taxi Driver
description:
From daVinci website:

Taxi Driver is a board game for 3-7 players, who drive around the city looking for passengers. The map of the city is different every time you play, because it is composed by placing at random a grid of 16 tiles. Each round, five “destinations” are drafted; all the players, at the same time, try to mentally find the quickest route to drive five passengers home, starting from the taxi parking lot. The player declaring to use the least amount of time possible may win the round, but before he needs to take his taxi and drive his way through streets and traffic lights in order to prove he really is the fastest.
categories: Abstract Strategy, Print & Play, Puzzle, Racing, Transportation
mechanics: Modular Board, Pattern Recognition, Point to Point Movement, Tile Placement

name: Scrabble Upper Hand
description: Players compete for high score by forming words, only in this version there are bridge aspects such as bidding and trick-taking. Tiles have suits on them. A Yahtzee-style scoring notepad is included, which contains boxes to fill out for contracts, declarations, trick scores and word scores. All in all, Upper Hand is a strange meld of Scrabble and Bridge, a combination which proved to be unsuccessful sales-wise.

name: Mastermind Secret Search
description:
Be the first player to correctly guess your opponent's secret word!

Players take turns guessing letters on their opponent's secret word. After incorrect guesses, the player learns if the letter is above or below their guess on the alphabet by sliding arrows along the alphabet columns.

This game includes two consoles and a wipe-off pen.

Re-implements:

Mastermind

name: Spökjägarna
description:
Players are trying to catch the ghost in the mansion. First they must track down the ghost, and then convince the owner of the mansion to let them use a gadget to catch the ghost. Meanwhile, players will also try to stop their opponents. Finally, they need to catch the ghost. The first player to do this is the winner.

Contents:
6 pawns
6 tiles
Gameboard
6 gadgets
2 dice
various chits
a cloth bag

6 years and up
mechanics: Map Deformation, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Mont-à-mots
description: The goal is to be the first player to reach the top of his mountain. To do so, each player draw a tile picturing something. If the first letter of the image is on your mountain, you "climbed" it.

name: El juego de los descendientes
description:
Game based on Disney's movie and series Descendants.

Players must travel along the path and end up memorizing a spell to defeat "Maléfica".

4 kind of tests: drawing in the air, mirror mirror, skill with Tourney's ball, and mimicking.

Player throws the dice, falls in a place and must do what a card says, according the color of the "square" where they landed. If you fail, you must go back to the "square" you were coming from.

First to reach the last "square" and memorizing three random weird words that make a spell wins.

name: Laws and Disorder
description:
From The Game Crafter's website:

"It was a time of great corruption, and also of great wealth for those who knew the secrets of the court and could turn it in their favor. In Laws and Disorder, you play noblemen in a land ruled by ever-changing laws, and must bribe and bully the court into passing laws which benefit you, or harm your opponents.

Each player has one of six different professions which grant them certain abilities. The shrewd Trader may buy additional assets, while the cunning Thief can steal from other players. The deck contains words which players combine into laws that everyone must obey. The Trader might make a law stating The Theif loses 2 cards when they use an ability, which should put a stop to the Thief's meddling - for awhile.

Things get interesting when the Doctor, Priest and Banker manipulate existing laws, and when the Thief gives up his life of crime to swap professions with another player. The result is a game which is never the same twice, and will keep you looking for new ways to turn the situation to your advantage.

Laws and Disorder is best played with 4-6 players and ample table space, although it makes for a longer and more strategic game with 2-3 players. Package includes deck plus rules. You must provide pocket change, play money or peanuts to use as game currency - I leave this choice up to you.

Want to try before you buy? You can also play Laws and Disorder in your browser on Whirled.com."

name: Warhammer 40,000: Wargear
description: Not to be confused with the 2nd edition rulebook of the same name, this expansion to Warhammer 40,000 4th edition includes rules and stats for various weapons and for shooting in general within the game, plus some vehicles rules and upgrades for both infantry and vehicles.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Miniatures, Science Fiction
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Variable Player Powers

name: Wrangled!
description: Wrangled! is a fast-paced card game of Cowboys and Cattledrives for 2-4 players that takes about 30-45 minutes to play. Players can choose to Draw, Trade, Build, or Attack on their turns, using either Cow or Cowboy cards in their hands to score points on the Cattledrive that forms during the game. Have the most Claimed Cows at the end of the game to win!

name: Pop Stream
description: It’s the ultimate Movie Trivia game experience! Watch hundreds of real movie clips stream on your tablet as two teams go head-to-head in a game of cinema smarts. Think you know the answer? Hit the “Buzz In” button on the game board, and then wager an amount to win or lose. Pop Stream is packed full of over 10 different types of questions and challenges to stump you and your team. And did we mention you can take SELFIES? Simply take your photo and attach it to your in-game character to see a hilarious animated version. Pop Stream combines your favorite movie scenes with the excitement of a game show, right in your living room. Test your movie knowledge with Pop Stream, the ultimate movie trivia game!

name: Calypso
description: A partnership card game that each player uses the cards won in tricks to form calypsos (all 13 cards of a the players given suit) for herself and her partner. Four regular decks are shuffled together but only 52 are used each hand. Each player has her own trump each hand.
publishers: Arrco Playing Card Co., Association of American Playing Card Manufacturers, De La Rue, John Waddington Ltd., The United States Playing Card Company, Waddingtons

name: PARKS Memories: Boxed Set
description:
Collection box for:
PARKS Memories: Plains Walker
PARKS Memories: Mountaineer
PARKS Memories: Coast to Coast

PARKS Memories is a strategic matching game for two or more players offering simple and flexible gameplay. Parks are represented in tiles laid out in a grid across the table face down. Gameplay includes four simple steps: reveal two tiles; choose one of the revealed tiles and place it in front of you; add a new tile to the board; lock one of the tiles with the hiker token. Gameplay passes from person to person until one player or team has collected three sets of matching park tiles in front of them.

Memories captures a depth of strategy in player abilities which can be activated by finding matches of PARKS resource icons when you reveal tiles. There are a variety of ways to enjoy the game. Play a head to head game, or on teams. Expand the grid size for a bigger challenge, or simplify the game to a memory game without player abilities for younger gamers.

PARKS Memories: Plains Walkers is one of three editions of PARKS Memories, highlighting the national parks of the plains region of the United States. It features a uniques set of player abilities. Collectively all three editions showcase every US national park.

name: Peep War
description:
Peep War! is a downloadable miniatures-based wargame that uses Marshmallow Peeps and jellybeans instead of expensive plastic and pewter miniatures. It is avaliable for free at http://www.invisible-city.com/play/156

Each player begins with a number of Peeps and jellybeans, and a supply Center. The game ends when one player has seized 80% of the supply centers on the playing field, or is the last player remaining in the game.

The Peeps are resource providers. When a Peep is at a Supply Center, then additional jellybeans can be brought into play. The jellybeans are the soldiers and are primarily used for attacking and claiming territory.

Conflict between jellybeans is resolved by placing all beans in the conflict in an easter egg and drawing one out at random. The side that controls the bean drawn wins that combat and gets to eat one opposing bean.

name: Blind Ignorance
description:
On your forehead you have a card that names you as a famous person, dead or alive. Everybody can see it and knows who you are - except you! You have to discover your mystery identity by interrogating the other players: Am I dead? Am I fat? Can I sing? Am I a bore? Personalities range from cartoon characters, to politicians, to movie stars. There's a limit to how many questions you can ask - so choose carefully. The more questions it takes, the lower the player's score.

Contents:
100 famous names on cards, 1 headband, instructions

name: Dark Heaven Apocalypse
description:
Dark Heaven: Apocalypse (DH:A) is a miniatures game set in the fantasy world of Adon. Players assume the roles of commanders of armies of fantastic races such as humans, vampires, dwarves, elves, etc., fighting among themselves and against the ultimate villains, the Dire-Dead, who are led by the Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse.

In DH:A, the 10-sided die is used to generate the random results to determine the outcome of battles, spells, and incidents. Players build up armies of equivalent point values to fight each other. The point value of a basic unit can be cheap, but can be increased by giving the unit better weapons, skills and spells. Players are free to customize the standard units presented in the rulebook or create their own. Rules also cover artillery, morale, chariots and elephants.

The battles are split into turns, which are further split into class movement phases (where increasingly more mobile units act ahead of slower ones). During a turn, Class 1 units (the most mobile) act first. The player who won the roll for initiative at the start of the turn enacts his or her orders for her Class 1 units before the opponent moves theirs. They then repeat the same for their Class 2, Class 3, and lastly Class 4 units. Individual figures can be grouped together with a leader in combat, supporting their leader in its fight and dying together with it if its roll fails against an opponent.

The winning conditions for a battle can include total destruction of the enemy, seizing an objective, or fleeing the battlefield after being surrounded.

name: Knack den Code-X
description: Code - X is a strange little game that challenges players to make connections using wooden rods of variable length on dowels in movable wooden bases. In the solitaire game, you try to use all the connecting rods. In the multiplayer game, you try to create a situation that will prevent your opponent from making a connection.

name: Die Monstermacher
description:
The players must try to stitch together a monster and revive it. You collect body parts from graves, the gallows and from other players warehouses.

There is a nice rule controlling when you can steal from other players. You have a die that moves up or down one number when you perform certain actions. Others can steal from you when the amount of body parts in your warehouse exceeds or is equal to your die number. This balances things out and keeps the players stitching their monster together (using their cards) to keep their warehouses (card supply) from being raided.

Art may be too gruesome for the youngest players.

name: Caught-Cha!
description:
Description from box:

The object is to get rid of your cards.

You can play cards of the number stated or Bluff!!

But if you are caught bluffing, Caught-Cha!

You will have to draw more cards.

name: Goal Line Stand
description:
Remember Scrimmage (by SPI)? Well, Goal Line Stand is "Scrimmage done right." This is a game of tactical American football played on a hex grid field with each player represented by an individual counter.

The heart of the game is the movement system, which is complex and, IMHO, realistic. Player counters can occupy a hex center, a hex side or a hex corner (vertex). Players spend movement points to move forward (straight or diagonally), backward (ditto), or sideways. Players can be facing in 1 of 12 directions. However, not all types of movement and facing are possible at all times - it depends upon where the counter is located (hex center, side or corner), and upon the position played and game situation. Some movement bonuses are available.

Each player is rated for: mobility, power, blocking, tackling, rushing, running, passing & pass receptions. Substitutes are available at some positions. A player may be in 1 of 2 stances: decelerated (as at the snap) or accelerated. In an accelerated stance, a player can move much farther but has less maneuverability.

There are extensive rules governing illegal movement locations and player contact. Blocking, tackling & rushing are resolved (after contact) with percentage dice and a variety of die roll modifiers. Movement after contact differs depending upon success or failure of the attempt.

Fake and real handoffs are possible. Forward and lateral passing (fake and real) is handled in a realistic (and, again, complex) manner. Passes may be lobs, lofts or bullets - each is handled in a different way for passing accuracy calculations and the chance of a deflection or interception.

Like Scrimmage, Goal Line Stand ignores the kicking game. Fumbles and penalties are not accounted for. Four learning scenarios are provided and, in my experience, are necessary to grasp this unique game system.

The game still suffers from a problem inherent in the concept - moving each player in 1/2 second intervals means it can easily take an evening to play 4 downs (between experienced players). That said, it is an interesting play for true football fanatics.

name: Slick!
description:
Players buy shares in seven oil refining companies; each run by its largest shareholder.

The companies refine and sell oil and establish depots to supply distant customers. At the end of the game, company assets are divided up among the shareholders. The richest player is the winner.

name: Dig
description:
The dealer selects a calling card which will have 2 categories (e.g.: a city or a word ending in 'us') and then chooses one of the two categories listed. Then players use wands with a gummy end to dig out letters from a big pile of tiles to form an answer that correctly fits into the category selected. The first person to do so receives 1 share of the gold mine. 5 shares are exchanged for a gold bar and the winner is the first player with 3 gold bars.

Money and cards feature the Monopoly Man.
publishers: Brohm-Parker-Spiele, Denys Fisher Toys, Parker Brothers

name: Sand-Würmchen
description:
Sandwürmchen (Baby Sand Worms) was invented by Peter Lewe. The children get a box with real sand in it, complete with a plastic cover to keep the sand from running out. There are six spaces in the bottom of the box, into which the colorful baby sand worms are pressed until they are no longer visible. The box is then turned around several times, so that nobody can remember exactly where each color of worm is located any more! Each child then receives cards with baby worms of various colors, after which the game begins.

In turn order, each child tries to find a worm of the colour that matches their topmost card. This they do by carefully digging in the sand. What color appears? If it's the right one, then that child gets to try and reveal a worm that matches their next card. If it's the wrong one, then maybe he'll have better luck next time, once several worms have been discovered. The box is turned around at the end of each round, so players have to pay close attention to where the worms are! At the end of the game, once all cards have been assigned to their worms, each child gets to place a marker where they think a worm of the matching colour is located. Then comes the exciting ending: one child gets to rattle the box until all of the worms have poked their heads out of the sand. Who was able to guess right?

Games by player age|Ages 4 and up.

name: The Sir Francis Chichester Game
description:
Game commemorating Sir Francis Chichister's solo world circumnavigation in 1966/1967.

The game's object is to be the first player to sail from Plymouth to Sydney, and then from Sydney, around the Horn, to Plymouth again.

name: Ball-Roll
description:
A magazine game from Jeux et Stratégie #23

A violent goal-scoring game between two teams mounted on roller-skates.

Appears to be inspired by the SF film "Rollerball"
categories: Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction, Sports

name: Gülle Gülle
description:
From the rules:

Players buy cows and fields. The cows produce fertilizer. Fields can be fertilized with the fertilizer. The fertilizer helps the corn to grow. Each player tries to harvest as many ears of corn as possible. Corn is the means of payment for additional resources - and is worth victory points at the end of the game.

name: Meatbot Massacre
description:
From the designers' website:

You are one of the few ultra-violent psychos left on the planet. You and the other un-treatable freaks squeeze into the squishy cockpits of bio-engineered war machines to face each other in televised gladiatorial combat. You are a meat jock and this is Meatbot Massacre.

Meatbot Massacre is a tactical game designed by Greg Stolze (Hunter: the Reckoning, Unknown Armies, GODLIKE) with Daniel Solis (PUNK, Gears & Spears) to provide an optimal mix of game speed, ease of use, and tactical complexity. Meatbot Massacre uses an innovative dice mechanic in which your choice of die-type determines your actions. The dice do the talking.

The core mechanic takes only minutes to learn, but the tactics get more intricate as your meatbot rips power-ups from enemies and devours them. In other words, you can make the game as simple or as complex as you want: When you've mastered it at its simplest, you can crank it up without learning new mechanics.

You can download the game for free at: http://www.danielsolis.com/meatbot/

name: Buzztime Trivia
description: Buzztime Trivia (4 different genres) is the card game equivalent of the NTN trivia that is prevalent in Sports Bars.

name: Rotkäppchen
description:
A fairy tale game for 2 or 3 kids from 5 to 9 years

Each player is either Rotkäppchen (Little Red Riding Hood), the Wolf or the Hunter. Each player has another goal:
-Red Riding Hood wins, if she reaches her granny's home before the hunter captures the Wolf
-The Hunter wins, if he captures the Wolf before Riding Hood reaches her granny's home
-The Wolf wins, if he captures Red Riding Hood, before she reaches her granny's home

Three houses, some trees and a bridge, all made from wood, can be placed more or less randomly on the board, which has a 16 by 16 squares printed over a forest seen from bird's view. A dice is thrown for movement - whenever the dice shows a "K" (for "Karte" or card) an event card is drawn (there are different event cards for each character).
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Abteilung: WW2 Battle Rules for 15mm Figures and Models
description:
Extract from Design and Philosophy "War is Hell" section of the rules:

These rules are intended to cover actions of divisional size. In the main it is intended that players consider their forces to be of about 5 battalion strength.
These rules have been kept simple in mechanism in order to provide the players with an opportunity to explore tactics, scenarios and have some fun too. The player is in the position of overall commander. This means that the minutiae of detailed decisions are not always his concern (it would be bad generalship to keep checking subordinates for correct actions), thus the rules allow for unpredictable things to happen. These rules partition the figures and models into commands. A command represents a battalion sized formation.
categories: Book, Miniatures, Wargame, World War II

name: Ärligt talat...
description: "Ärligt talat" (Honestly spoken) is a Swedish trivia game that tells the truth about what your friends like and don't like.

name: Trivial Pursuit: Genus Kartensatz – 2400 Fragen und Antworten
description: 2400 new Cards for the Genus edition of the famous Trivial Pursuit trivia game.
categories: Expansion for Base-game, Party Game, Trivia

name: Drachenreiter
description:
The players accompany the dragon Lung, the dwarven girl Schwefelfell (Sulfurskin), the human boy Ben and a young woman on their journey to the border of the sky - the last place of refuge for dragons.

Players contribute to defeat the evil dragon Nesselbrand (Nettle) in this tactical movement game. How much did you contribute at game end, when the bad dragon is defeated?

name: Hell's Kitchen: The Board Game
description:
Welcome to Hell's Kitchen, where the chef's word is law. As the latest trainees in the kitchen, you have a full day ahead of you. It's not simply a matter of serving cool culinary creations, there's a lot of hard work first. The day starts with preparing the ingredients for today's menu. Only then can you start cooking - and you'd better have everything ready by the time service starts. And meet chef's standards.

In the game, players prepare ingredients according to the recipes for the dishes they're cooking. They can take advantage of the ingredients other players prepare to get their dish ready quickly. Then it's time for service and we find out who's got it right - and whose dishes are going in the bin. Remember: if you can't take the heat, stay out of Hell's Kitchen!

Similar to Mamma Mia!, but now with a new theme and some new rules.

name: Uncle Chestnut's Card Gype
description:
Almost 100 years after G.K. Chesterton and H.G. Wells created "the well-known and widespread national game of Gype" mentioned in Chesterton's Autobiography, Uncle Chestnut's Card Gype arrived on the scene.

Players use a 54 card deck to assemble items from Uncle Chestnut's pockets into topics for his lectures and books. The rules are simple, but ever-changing.

Card Gype features over 40 quotations from G.K. Chesterton, who was the basis for the fictional character "Uncle Chestnut."

This game is based on the Fluxx® game engine, designed by Andrew Looney, and is used with an understanding from Looney Labs®.

name: Time No Time
description:
Roberto Fraga returns with another game in the spirit of Dancing Eggs, a game that asks you to do six impossibly silly things before breakfast.

In Time No Time, players are confronted with a deck of 100+ cards and a timer that beeps 0-90 seconds after it's been started. When a round of play begins, the first player draws a card and does whatever the card tells her to do: Touch something red in the room; recite her name backwards; place the card on her head, squat, then stand again without dropping the card, run around the table, and so on.

As soon as the player finishes her action, she passes the card deck to the next player. If the timer buzzes while you're holding the deck, you receive a lightning marker as penalty. Collect three lightning bolts, and you're struck down, losing the game while everyone else wins.

name: Quick Picks Family Feud Game
description:
From the publisher:

The Survey Says... Now even MORE fun for everyone! The Family Feud Quick Pick edition features 45 rounds of survey questions and answers to one of America's longest running and most beloved TV Game Shows. With everything from the Face Off to the Feud to the Fast Money Round, The Family Feud Quick Pick edition offers all the fun of the TV show in this convenient travel-friendly tin! So play, pass, and steal your way to victory. The top eight answers are on the board, do you know what the "SURVEY SAYS"?!! Contents: Scoreboard, Strike Indicator, 3 "X" Markers, Instruction/Survey Question Booklet, 1 Dry Erase Marker

name: Game Developerz: Legendary Developerz
description:
Set of exclusive cards offered Kickstarter project reward above a certain tier.

All the Legendary Devs will have an upkeep cost of 3 coinz per turn.

The cards have a new background to distinguish them from the core set.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Humor, Video Game Theme

name: Draw 4: Dig for Dinos
description: In Draw 4: Dig for Dinos, you are a paleontologist digging through the dirt on an expedition to complete your dinosaur bone collection! Players try to collect complete sets of dinosaur bones by taking turns picking either an Action Tile or Dinosaur Tile from the grid, while collecting cards may be limited by their location or by another player's actions! Expose and collect the most dinosaur bones and become a world-renowned paleontologist!

name: Imperial Harvest: Broomstick Monkey
description:
User Summary
Broomstick Monkey is a promotional character card for the game Imperial Harvest. The character is based on the publisher's mascot of the same name and was included as a bonus with the Kickstarter edition of the game. The Broomstick Monkey may fly over hedges and, in the advanced game, is not affected by ranged attacks. While carrying a strawberry, the Broomstick Monkey may carry any number of items.
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Set Collection, Variable Player Powers

name: Mech Capture
description:
Description from the designer:

Introduction
Our enemy is rich in resources, but weak-minded. Many of their Mechs are bigger, faster, and stronger than ours. But challenge their mercenary pilots and they give up quickly and leave their machines.

We control 3 of the 6 sectors around their base, and we’re moving in for the kill. As their Mechs retreat to defend their base, we will attempt to surround and capture them. Capture them if you can, destroy them if you must.

We are closer than we have ever been to a major victory against the Federation. It is all in your hands now. Don’t fail us.

Game Overview
Mech Capture is a solitaire print and play card game using 36 cards - no dice, cubes, or other components needed.

As enemy and friendly units appear on the battlefield, take charge of friendly units and deploy them in pairs to surround enemy Mechs, or in triplets to surround enemy Mechs, Transports, or Long Range Guns at their base.

A limited number of friendly units may be placed in your Reserves for future deployment. Deploy these units to match the enemy’s displayed characteristic and number of pilots, to capture the Mech and gain its Victory Points. If you exceed their displayed characteristic, the Enemy unit is destroyed so that the Enemy (or you) cannot gain its Victory Points.

Winning the Game
By game end have more Victory Points than the Enemy. Compare your victory points from captured units to all remaining enemy units at their base, three sectors, and Enemy draw pile (if any).
categories: Card Game, Print & Play, Science Fiction, Wargame

name: Superfight: The Street Fighter Deck
description: The world's most legendary fighting franchise is now in your Superfight cards. Use these cards on their own or with any other Superfight decks to bring classics like Ryu, Chun-li, and M. Bison off the screen and onto your table for the most epic battles you've ever argued about.
categories: Card Game, Expansion for Base-game, Fighting, Party Game, Video Game Theme

name: Ice Dice
description: Discover the secret life of Santa in Ice Dice! Practice basic arithmetic operations: roll the dice and use the values of the dice and either addition, subtraction, multiplication, or division to obtain a new number and move the corresponding token from one board to another. Collect the best combination of tokens on your player board to win!

name: UNO: Marvel Ultimate Spider-man Web-Warriors Card Game
description:
With great power comes great fun in this Ultimate Spider-Man edition of UNO game!
Get yourself out of a sticky situation with the special "Web Slinger" card!
Listen to your Spidey-Sense and yell "UNO!" before you play your last card!
—description from the publisher

This variant of UNO differs in that there are 'web slinger' wild cards. They are wild plus you get to 'sling' up to 3 cards from your hand, all of the same color, to other players' hands (however you choose).
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Comic Book / Strip

name: Beekeeper
description:
As any Beekeeper worth their weight in wax, knows the queen is central to the health of the hive. In this fun new card game, you handle the hives as your swarm of drones and queens is flipped and rearranged. Create two colonies before your opponents do.

Game Play:
Shuffle the deck of cards. Each player draws 16 cards face down from the deck. Then, each player makes two piles of 8 cards face down (4x2 grids). These are their two hives.

On a player’s turn they will choose any card (except for their first turn where each player must choose their queen) and replace a face down card with the chosen card face up. The player will look at the card they chose and put it in the corresponding numbered location in the hive.

Players will continue to replace face down cards with each new card in their hand until you can no longer play any more cards.

If the overturned card is a queen, move it over to the other hive and start working on both hives at the same time. Once a queen is placed into a hive, she cannot be moved out. However, the queen is a wild card and can be moved around within the hive

When a player draws a card they can’t play, they discard it into the discard pile and then their turn is over.

The winner is the first person to complete two hives. Each hive must have a queen and the rest of the numbers in order and all turned face up

name: Lost In Translation
description:
The party game Lost in Translation consists of a deck of clue cards and a pad of blank answer sheets. There are 3 kinds of cards in the deck:

1) Pictures of signs, packages, menus, etc with one or more words obscured by questions marks and a notation of a non-English language. Players will need to guess the word(s) obscured by the question marks.

2) Movie Titles in English with a notation of a country where that movie was translated into a non-direct translation. Players will need to provide their best guess of the translated movie title in that country. (For example, you might guess that Star Wars in China might be translated into "Space Adventures".)

3) Idioms in a non-English language with a direct translation into English and a notation about the language the idiom comes from originally. Players will need to guess what the idiom is actually about.

The game is played over 10 rounds. Each round, one player will act as the editor and select 1 random card, and then read the language / country and show the picture, read the movie title, or the translated idiom.

The editor writes down the actual answer and collects everyone's answer sheets and reviews them. If anyone gets the answer correct, they score points and the answer is not used. The editor then reads the remaining answers in random order.

Players vote on which answer they believe to be correct. Points are given for those who guess the correct answer and for those who got others to vote for their answer. The editor also grants a bonus point for their favorite answer - often a humorous answer.

The editor rotates to a new player each round and after 10 rounds, the player with the most points wins the game.

name: Dragamonz
description:
Are YOU ready to throw down with some of the bravest, silliest, and most epic creatures you’ve ever seen? Good! Get ready to smash, collect, and battle with 'Dragamonz, the newest collectible and trading card game!

Smash open an egg to reveal the half-animal, half-dragon figure inside and collect up to 72 different characters. Each character comes with trading cards that can be used in a battling card game for further extended play.

Each turn you select one of your Dragamonz and choose which of your oponnent's Dragamonz you want to face. You then both draw two cards from your custom selected deck belong to each dragamonz. Flip the cards to see who wins.

Quick, easy entry level TCG that can be a great entry level game to teach young players deck construction.

—description from the publisher

name: Etsi ja löydä: Safariseikkailu
description:
A reimplementation of Muumi viidakkoseikkailu and Coral Reef, Etsi ja löydä Safariseikkailu is a game of fast reactions that has the players flipping two cards and trying to find the animals depicted in the cards from the board as soon as possible.

First player to find both animals scores a point, five points wins the game. Some rounds reward players with camera tokens and it's also possible to win the game by collecting two camera tokens.

name: Khedu The Card Game
description:
Khedu The Card Game is a fast paced 1-4 player fantasy card game where players compete against each other to build combat configurations with cards and dice. The objective is to earn as many points as you can before taking your last turn. Players spend energy to deploy heroes and spells -and earn points by building rewarding combat configurations.

The game ends when the last player has spent all their Energy tokens and completes their last turn. The player with the most points at the end of the game wins

-description from publisher
mechanics: Card Play Conflict Resolution, Push Your Luck

name: Disney/Pixar Toy Story: Talent Show
description: Step right up and show off your talents in a friendly competition of card play and challenges! You’ll be balancing, tossing, roping, and rolling your way to winning the most Prize Tickets! Players collect Prize Tickets for performing Talents and playing out their cards. At the end of the game, the player with the most points on their Prize Tickets wins!

name: Sovereign of the Seas
description:
It is a game of naval shipping and trading set in the late 17th early 19th century. The board is a map of Europe and of the many areas where the European powers had colonies (Africa, Asia, Carribean, N & S. America). There are 32 ports depicted on the map and the shipping lanes connecting the ports. Also in the game are cargo charts - which show what goods are sold in each of the ports, port cards which list the ports and the price to buy the port, destination cards which list a port (some ports have more than 1 card depending on how busy that port was in real life), and cargo cards which represent each of the 9 types of goods in the game, and finally weather and pirate random event cards.

The game starts by all players drawing destination cards and a cargo card. You then roll the dice and move your ship from your home port to a port that sells the trade good that you need which you then buy and transport to the destination port. During the game all ports can be bought and if owned you have to pay a premium to the owner if you use that port. You win by collecting 150,000.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Hex-Meister
description:
The board shows a series of concentric hex-gridded spaces, of varying colors. The two white rings ("lanes") allow movement limited only by the presence of other pieces. The three blue rings ("moats") cannot be crossed in one go; you must stop on them. The lone exceptions are the four blue hexes on your side of the board --you may cross them freely, but your opponent cannot. The thirteen red hexes ("gates"), finally, are the game goals; you win by occupying five of these in a straight line. To enter a gate, you must start adjacent to it (except for the two gates adjacent to your base). Entering a gate (other than the two base ones) gives you a bonus move. Occupied gates are the only occupied spaces that can be jumped.

A hex is "secured" (the opponent cannot enter it) if surrounded by three or more of your pieces. Securing a hex captures any piece that happens to lie there (it is removed from the game and you get a bonus move). Finally, the fifth gate of any triangular set is secured if you occupy the first four. This is called "triangulation".

The rulebook also supplies handicapping suggestions, optional rules for a more challenging game, and explains how to support team play.
mechanics: Enclosure, Grid Movement, Hexagon Grid, Pattern Building
publishers: Hex-Meister Inc., John N. Hansen Co., Inc.

name: Das Gurkensolo
description:
The game features a race of four wooden cucumbers along 12 numbered fields. Each player draws a card showing the order in which the cucumbers should pass the finishing line.
In every turn each player picks two cards containing statements about the race's standings, e.g. "The red cucumber is not ahead of the green cucumber." Now the player must choose one cucumber to move forward by one field or two, if he succeeds in making one of the two statements true and the other one false after his or her move.
The player whose order of cucumbers matches the race's outcome best wins the game.

name: Slideways
description: Get ready to flip out with this flip 'n slide game of tic-tac-toe! Slideways is a fast-paced puzzle game of logic and skill that raises the bar on fun as players try to outwit their opponents. Move your bar on the board or flip colors to get four in a row. Is it as easy as it seems?

name: Blind Faith
description:
Against the Odds #59

Blind Faith: The Hussite Wars 1419-1434

In A.D. 1415, at the Council of Constance, Jan Hus and Jerome of Prague, two church reformers from Bohemia, were burnt at the stake for heresy. In the years that followed, outrage over the execution convulsed civil society in Bohemia, a fief of the Holy Roman Empire. Now, with Bohemia in rebellion as well as consumed by heresy, the Emperor Sigismund must wage war to both extirpate the heresy and secure his throne.

The Hussite player's forces are largely Bohemians (i.e. Czech) and others, who, inspired by the teachings of Jan Hus, supported the taking of Communion with both bread and wine, along with other reforms of the Roman Catholic Church. The Hussites are in turn divided into two to three factions: the Calixtenes (Moderates), the Taborites (Radicals), and a later splinter group called Orphans. Moderates preferred to reform the church, while radicals wanted more comprehensive reforms, not only of the church, but of the state and society. Some even rejected church and monarchy. The Imperial player controls those forces under the Emperor and King, Sigismund of Luxembourg. (Note: Sigismund was still only King of the Romans in 1420. Although he was not crowned emperor by the Pope until 1433, he was still the ruler of Germany, in a nominal sense anyway.) They support the execution of Hus and oppose the taking of Communion with both bread and wine. Royal Crusaders, including both the Catholic minority in Bohemia and the Kingdom of Hungary are also under the direct control of the Imperial player. Papal Crusaders from the Holy Roman Empire (i.e. Germany) are under the indirect control of the Imperial player.

This bitter and sustained struggle devastated large parts of the empire in a manner not seen again until another religious conflict, the Thirty Years War, took place in roughly the same regions. The Imperial player must destroy the heretics and retake Bohemia before the Pope is forced to make concessions in another church council. The Hussite player, led by the devout, blind and gifted military leader, Jan Zizka, must prevent this and try to begin a Reformation in Europe one hundred years early.

Designed by Jason Juneau, Blind Faith depicts a classic example of asymmetric warfare, granting both players many options in waging war. The resources and position of the Imperial side are pitted against the skill and morale of the Hussite side. Storming and besieging towns become part of players' strategies for loot and victory. This war was part of a larger sea change in warfare in Europe. Knights and peasants, artillery and threshing flails, clergy and laymen were thrown together in a war the signaled the demise of the feudal system and the universal church.

—description from the publisher

name: Aunt Agatha's Attic
description:
Family is the most important treasure of all — for now!

You and your cousins may not like each other very much, but you all love your Aunt Agatha — and her vast collection of treasures from around the world! In the fast and frenzied card game Aunt Agatha's Attic, you must race against the clock to bargain with your cousins for the best of Agatha's collection, simultaneously trading glowing emeralds, bone-handled daggers, and even selfless hugs before time runs out. Can you work together to show your aunt just how important family is, all while keeping the best stuff for yourself?

—description from the publisher

name: Trivial Pursuit: World Football – Bite-Size
description:
Now you can test your World Cup football knowledge wherever you go! This handy pack contains 600 questions. You can play it anywhere as a stand-alone game using the special die or add questions to your standard Trivial Pursuit! Includes questions on players, teams, rules and regulations, fans, World Cup, trophies and more!

This is another in the "Bite-Size" range of Trivial Pursuit games. It is intended as a portable travel game. The game is packaged in a wedge ("piece-of-pie") shaped box.

The game does not feature a game board, and thus, there is no roll-and-move mechanic. Instead, players roll the color-coded die, and answers a question matching the color rolled. If a player correctly answers a question, he may "go for a wedge" by answering another question in the same category. If he does so, he keeps that card. If the player answers a question incorrectly, it is the next player's turn. Play ends when a player has collected six cards/correctly answered 12 questions.
categories: Card Game, Party Game, Sports, Trivia
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move
publishers: Hasbro, Horn Abbot International, Parker Brothers, Parker Spiele

name: Star Wars Mos Eisley Shoot-Out
description: This mini-game was included in an issue of SHADIS magazine and serves primarily as a means of introducing the base mechanics of West End Games' Star Wars roleplaying game. Battles are played out on a small, 12X22 grid map, simulating combat at the Mos Eisley Spaceport. It comes with 5 different scenarios, or all can be played to form a small campaign with cumulative Victory Points indicating ultimate victory. One player controls the imperial troops of storm troopers and bounty hunters, while the other controls the rebels - a smuggler, Rebel sergeant, Wookie and X-Wing pilot (and occasionally a U-THR droid).
categories: Fighting, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Science Fiction

name: Word Rummy
description:
A simple Rummy game that tests players' vocabulary and their ability to form anagrams.

Each player is dealt seven 'letter' cards. On their turn they have three options:

1. Form and meld one word of three or more letters
2. Change one word previously placed by adding letters from your hand (this allows you to 'steal' an opponent's word)
3. Draw one card from the draw deck and discard one card

When the draw deck runs out and players are unable to form or change words, the round ends and points are scored. Points are awarded for words based on their length, bonus points are awarded for words of six or more letters.

A number of rounds are played to reach a set goal... usually 25 or 50 points.

name: Pfad-Finder
description:
With the 33 way-tiles and some extra pieces (like an oak, a castle, a bus-stop...) a path is build on the table that the players have to recognize.
On their turn players have their pawn moved by describing which way they take and in which direction they're turning. Whoever reaches the end of the path first is the winner.

Small game which requires a huge portion of memorizing.
publishers: Schmidt Spiele, Selecta Spel en Hobby

name: Space Dogfight
description:
Space Dogfight is the second game in the Game-o-gram series. All games in the Game-o-gram series should fit on a postcard and should preferably contain everything needed to play.

The basic idea of the game is that it should be cheap enough for everyone to buy, easy enough for everyone to play and interesting enough to play over again.

Space Dogfight is a rapid two-player game where the players will challenge each other in a brutal and ultimate space duel, using custom-made fleets of space ships.

This game is not only available as a postcard game, but also as a free print-n-play game! The print-n-play document (PDF) is downloadable in the Files section below, and it contains the same things found on the postcard, i.e. game board, counters and rules.
mechanics: Action Points, Grid Movement, Square Grid
publishers: (Self-Published), (Web published), Mr. Do, Print & Play Productions

name: Trivial Pursuit: Travel Edition
description:
A travel variant of the famous Trivial Pursuit game. The object is to answer questions in different color-coded categories, and to win "wedges" with correct answers. The first person to win a wedge of each color wins the game.

The game comes with a plastic container that can be split into two parts forming the player's "cake" and cards container. Played by 2 players or teams.
publishers: Hasbro, Horn Abbot International, MB Juegos, Parker Brothers, Parker Spiele

name: Are We There Yet?
description: A travel card game played by anyone. Recommended for Ages 7 and upwhile traveling in a vehicle. Time and distance go by unnoticed, as each player tries to spot the most items appearing on their travel cards before reaching their destination. There are 450 travel cards in 5 categories: objects, people, signs, vehicles, and animals as well as 50 short cut cards. The game can be played competitively, as a group or in teams and has 10 variations of play, including Bumper Cards, Demolition Derby, Splat and Open Road. There is no game board, dice or markers necessary and comes ready to play.
publishers: Family Games, Inc., Paul Lamond Games Ltd, Piatnik

name: My Very First Games: Let's Cook
description:
Every dish you make is sure to be a success. A large helping of sorting, a heaping spoonful of puzzle solving, and a dollop of memory fun will make it happen. Let's Cook includes three different games that have children practice recognizing and naming vegetables and other foods, guessing their fellow players? Favorite ingredients, or remembering what's needed for a recipe. Play together and find a love for cooking round after round. Get to the kitchen, it's dinner time!

—description from the publisher

name: Le jeu des incollables
description:
French game of questions with a typical course "Game of the Goose" of which each box, will define the theme of the question which will be put to you.
The winner is of course, the one who finishes the course first.
The difference with other question sets is that the questions are calibrated here according to the level of the player.
Each card offers a question for each grade level from CP to CM2 and a question for older adults and adults.

name: In a World of Dinosaurs
description:
In a World of Dinosaurs is a territory and resource collection game for 2-4 players where you play simultaneously as Paleontologists in the present, and Dinosaurs in the past, on two separate boards. One board represents the island millions of years ago, and the other represents the island around the early 1900’s
Players defend their land from opposing teams, expand their territory, and explore the jungle for artifacts, all the while strategically fossilizing dinosaurs in areas of the island they control.

As they kill off these dinosaurs, players assemble their fossilized remains, and send them off to the museum to start attracting visitors. Sure, they may be narrowly avoiding certain death while they do so, but who isn’t?

The better the dinosaurs, the more visitors walk into your museum. The dinosaurs can be assembled in any combination (for example Tyran-dactyl), to immediately attract visitors, or players can hold out to assemble matching parts for more points.
categories: Adventure, Exploration, Humor, Prehistoric, Territory Building
mechanics: Area Majority / Influence, Area Movement, Dice Rolling, Hand Management, Push Your Luck, Set Collection, Trading

name: Doghouse
description:
This is a checkers variant where three dice are held in a plastic block. When "thrown" they indicate which pieces you may move this turn, yours or your opponent's - all except the opposing king(s). Adds some strategy elements to a simple game, but it's still checkers. Fun for families.

From an web game store:

Are you a lucky dog? Shake the Dog House Dice Shaker to determine your moves and slide the dog bowls across the checkerboard kitchen floor. Collect your opponent's bowls by jumping over them. Get rewarded with bone treats, but watch out for double jumps and triple jumps or you will really be in the dog house! The first player to capture all the bowls wins!

name: Mad Scientist: Monster Lab Escape
description:
This board game was part of the Mad Scientist line of toys. Players mold monsters out of `monster flesh' clay and try to get them to escape the lab. In addition to trap door and acid spill (lose a turn) squares there are many squares that allow you to mash your opponent's monsters.

Components include a spinner, monster flesh, a monster mold, monster feet and hats in four colors, and four different monster mashers (one for each player).

name: Perception
description: The game is billed as "a mental adventure in psychological strategy". Some creative marketing on Ideal's part because the game is actually nothing more than a simple guessing game. Each player or team has three pieces that they are trying to move to the center of the board. On their turn, a player secretly chooses one of their pieces to move and holds the appropriately colored "tactile" for that piece in their closed hand. Their opponent now tries to guess which color they are holding. If their opponent guesses correctly, nothing happens. If they guess incorrectly, the player gets to move that colored piece one step forward on the board. When any two pieces get to the center of the board, the round is over and players score their position: +1 point for each piece in the middle of the board, -1 point for each piece left in the starting row. First player to five points wins.

name: Pop Yer Top
description: Players attempt to move the Koo-Koo Bird along the path from start to finish without causing him to pop his top. If the bird pops his top the player must go back and start again. Players move the bird any number of steps they dare, never knowing for sure when the bird will pop his top.
mechanics: Hand Management, Pick-up and Deliver, Point to Point Movement, Push Your Luck

name: Hot Wheels Wipe Out
description: Racing game based on the toy cars. Uses a spinner shaped like a tire to determine moves made on the board.

name: Kanto
description:
You have a board of 5*8 and each player has 20 pieces numbered from 1 to 19 (20= kanto) and are placed randomly and upside down on the board.
In your turn you can turn a piece (so that you see what number is on it) and take a lower numbered piece. The 'kanto' wins from every piece except the number one piece. The 15 wins from the 14 but loses from the 16 and so on. The pieces that are already won, are placed upside down next to the board. So you have to remember which pieces are out of the game.
publishers: MB Jeux, MB Spellen, MB Spiele, Milton Bradley

name: Mr. Who?
description:
3M published games in several different well-known packages - bookcase boxes, mini-bookcase gamettes, "butterbox" gamettes, and flatbox sports games. They also published a few games in other formats, one of which was the "crackerbox" format used for Mr. Who (Bid & Bluff is the only other game published in this box type).
The game, Mr. Who, is a somewhat unusual deduction game. There are 32 Suspect cards which show pictures like those on the outside of the box - the suspect is always the same man (Robert de Niro look-a-like) but could be wearing one of four different hats, sunglasses or not, and one of four differently-colored sweaters. There are also 32 Mr. Who cards which have written descriptions that match the Suspect cards, but with the characteristics in random order. In each round, one player is Mr. Who and picks a Mr. Who card - the other players are detectives and try to deduce which suspect he is. They play cards to the grid on the board to get information on the three items on the Mr. Who card. During this process Mr. Who commits more crimes and the reward money increases. After everyone has been Mr. Who once the player with the most money wins.
The board is made of vinyl. A little metal car is used to track Mr. Who's progress. The reward marker is a generic plastic pawn.

name: Grolsch Master Game
description:
From the back of the box:

Who is the film buff and who knows most about beer? Who is the sports freak of the party and who is Mr(s). Know-it-all? Maybe there's a talented sketch-artist or actor in the room. If you are blessed with all these talents, or you are just plain lucky, you stand a high chance to become 'Master of the Game'.

Play the Grolsch Master Game and test yourself. Play, roll the dice and become 'Master of the Game'.

Aim of the Game:
Try to reach the finish first with your swing-top bottle, pay the bill and win the game.

Gameplay synopsis With your swing-top bottle you travel from start to finish. Along the way you need to answer various questions or fulfill assignments. But watch out! Every ring brings you closer to the finish, but the questions and assignments become more difficult too. You go from one ring to the next via the doorman ar an open door. But... you don't reach the finish that easily. First you will need to make sure that you have paid your bill. With the beer voucher you won, you can pay the innkeeper. You win these vouchers by correctly answering the questions or fulfilling the assignments.

The Grolsch Master game is a promotional game from the Dutch brewery Grolsch, world famous (in the Netherlands) for it's swing-top bottles. The game is a party game that combines aspects of Trivial Pursuit, Pictionary, Charades etc.

The Trivia questions are divided into the categories Film, Beer, Sports and Various, each category containing 50 cards of 4 questions with increasing difficulty. The question you are asked depends on the ring you are in, the closer to the center, the more difficult the question should be. There are also 150 'the Pub' cards with 4 assignments that require you to draw, impersonate, act out or imitate persons, animals situations or even your thoughts on a particular matter (that you have written down beforehand). A sixth set of cards (30 brewery cards) are comparable to the 'Chance' cards of Monopoly.

You roll the die to determine the number of steps you have to take (you can decide whether you travel clockwise or counter clockwise), and depending on the square you land upon, you need to answer a question or carry out an assignment, you can get to the next ring or you get to draw a 'Brewery' (Chance) card. If you answer a question correctly, you get a beer voucher, otherwise you have to pay a beer voucher. If one of the other players guesses your assignment correctly, both get a beer voucher.

There a two possibilities to get to the next ring: via an open door, or via a doorman. The doorman requires payment in the form of beer vouchers. When you reach the final ring, you need to have enough beer vouchers to pay your bill. The first player reaching the inner circle wins the game.
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Paper-and-Pencil, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Questillo
description:
Questillo is a game of crossword building - each player has a grid on a sheet of paper, and adds words to it to make a crossword type layout.

The words added are based on clues, which come from cards drawn from a box. So a clue might say 'A great game', and each player has to get the name of a great game added to their existing set of words on their grid.

Think of a cross between 'Pictionary' and 'Scrabble', and you're nearly there...

Points are achieved for words accepted by everybody, and can be doubled or tripled on certain bonus squares. Most points wins!

name: Le compte est bon!
description:
This game is based on a famous French TV show in the 80ties called "Des chiffres et des lettres" (=numbers and letters).

Players are given 6 random numbers between 1-25. The object is by using basic mathematics (add/subtract/multiply/divide) to calculate a given three-figure number. After a preset amount of time players show their results. The one coming closest wins (that round).

If the result was correct, the TV presenter Jammot said his famous quote: "Le compte est bon!" which means the calculation was correct.

name: The Fugitive
description: A spin and move game for 2 to 4 players, based on the ABC television series of the same name. Comes with game board, 4 player pawns, spinner, and 32 cards.

name: Fleet 1715: Expansion
description: This small (6-card) expansion for Fleet 1715 includes 12 new solo scenarios for use with the original game. It also includes errata for the original game.
categories: Card Game, Deduction, Expansion for Base-game, Nautical

name: Dan Dare
description:
The game consists of a pack of 44 cards, picturing Dan Dare and his friends from the Eagle. There are four suits (Air Transport, Weapons, Land and Sea Transport and Animals) though in each suit the highest numbered cards are Dan Dare himself (11), Miss Peabody and Sir Hubert Guest (10) and Digby (9).

The game is a two part trick-taking card game. In the first half of the game the winner of each trick gets to take a visible top card from the remainder of the deck (the loser takes a hidden card) and in the second half the cards won in the first half are used.
categories: Card Game, Comic Book / Strip, Science Fiction
publishers: Pepys (Castell Brothers), Retro Range Toys and Games

name: Gorlice-Tarnow, 1915
description:
Gorlice-Tarnow covers the Eastern Front in World War 1, 1914-1916. Includes troops from Russia, Germany, Austria-Hungary, Turkey, Serbian, Rumania, Greek, Bulgaria, Italy, Britain, and France. The map (15 x 35, in 6 sections) stretches from Riga to Odessa. Each hex is 25 miles, and each turn a week.

The unique Army Group Command Control system prides itself on simulating "the utter stupidity of WW1 Generals." Six pages of rules cover standard wargame mechanics plus railroads, entrenchments, forts, subject peoples, political consequences, neutrals, weather, and sea transport. Scenarios are included for the campaigns of Lemberg, Gorlice, Brusilov, and a WW1 variant of Drang Nacht Osten!

This game was included in JagdPanther magazine #7 (an oversized issue) which has been rereleased in PDF format by Amarillo Design Bureau. It has amateur DTP production values. Rather large for a magazine game of its time!
publishers: Amarillo Design Bureau, Inc., JagdPanther Publications

name: Head of the Herd
description:
Description from BoardgameNews.com:

Head of the Herd, for three or more players, ages 8 and up, is a party game in the tradition of Quelf as players must follow the instructions on various cards each time while simultaneously avoiding what’s prohibited by the "Law of the Land" cards. Thus you might have to start your turn by bowing, then complete a task without using your thumbs and while having one hand on the table. Break the law, and you move closer to being eliminated from the game.

name: The Kids are All Right
description: An electronic board game based on the BBC show of the same name. Adults compete to win through four taxing rounds, but must beat kids aged 9 to 15 to take home the prize.
categories: Electronic, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia

name: Sudoku
description:
The game contains
1 main board
81 black cardboard pieces (digits from 1 to 9)
4 sets of 81 cardboard pieces (each set in different colour: red, green, yellow and blue)
1 booklet with tasks
1 hourglass
1 instruction

Players choose the task they are going to solve from the task booklet. They place black cardboard pieces according to the model from the booklet. Next each player chooses the colour of the cardboards pieces he is going to use on the board.

The oldest player starts the game, then other player follow clockwise. The player whose turn this is places the cardboard piece he is holding in his hand on an empty square. He/she must apply to the SUDOKU rule that inside each row, each column and each block a digit may appear only once. When the first player made his/her move, the next player places his/her cardboard piece on the board - of course, remembering about sudoku rule. The hourglass limits the length of turn. If the hourglass becomes empty and the player has not placed his/her cardboard piece yet, he/she misses his/her chance and it is the next player's turn.

The game stops when no player can place a cardboard piece on the board.
Then the players check the position of the cardboard pieces on the board in the answer booklet. If on the board there are misplaced cardboard pieces, we put them aside and each player counts his/her cardboard pieces that are on the board. The winner is the person who scores the biggest number of points.

name: França Antártica
description:
Brazilian postcard print-and-play wargame about the french attacks in Brazil on the 16 century.

Small, easy to print, learn and play, the games last 8 turns each divided in 3 phases (Initiative, movement, combat) in which the objective of the French/Indian player is to take the fort, and the Portuguese player to prevent it.

The board represents no specific place but a generic battleground.

Counters are divided in Portuguese, French and Indians.
It requires 2 d6 dice.
categories: Pike and Shot, Print & Play, Wargame

name: Runes & Ruin
description:
Once upon a time, when Shadow Lord the evil one swept across the land, the legendary Dragon Lord gathered the heroes and eventually defeated the Shadow Lord. The Dragon Lord, however, was seriously injured and eventually died, transformed into Runes, which are sealed with the shadows deep inside the temple. Now, the temple is long wasted, and the power of the enchantment has become weak, so weak that the power of shadows are leaking. The descendants of the heroes gather, march into the ruin to find the runes and seal the shadows again — but the shadow's followers have infiltrated the group.

Runes & Ruin is a fantasy partnership game designed for 4 to 6 players, with various characters of different abilities, and numerous artifacts that are the key to success. Players advance their team toward victory by exploring the ruin and attacking others. The heroes must find all the runes before the seal fails; the shadow follower must sabotage the heroes' plan. Depending on the number of players and the stage of the game, one to three shadow followers are hidden among the players, just as truths are always hidden underneath lies...

name: Shenanigans: The Musical
description: A social deduction game in which players are an orchestra full of players working at cross purposes to try to make something approaching music (or "an orchestra"). Each player receives a role and must decide how to use its power, whether to trade the role with another and what they will say to help the manager reach their final decision regarding who to eject from the orchestra. When the manager makes their choice the game ends and everyone wins or loses based on their role - the manager wants to catch the artiste, the artiste wants to escape, most musicians want the manager to sort things out but a few have their own agendas.
mechanics: Acting, Role Playing, Variable Player Powers

name: Zombies in our neighborhood
description: Zombies in our neighborhood is a solitaire card game using grid movement, dice rolls and resource management. It’s the zombie apocalypse and your neighborhood has been overrun by the living dead. You are ex-military and you just returned home from war when you realize the world has gone to hell in a hand basket. Your family is scattered throughout the neighborhood and you must rescue all of them. Your wife and two kids are holed up in different house throughout the neighborhood and you need to find them and bring them to safety; or as safe as you can be in a zombie apocalypse!
categories: Card Game, Dice, Print & Play, Zombies
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Grid Movement, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Picmix
description:
Description from the publisher:

In Picmix, each player has a set of four cards on which are shown sixteen items. Each turn, a goal card with three or four of these objects is revealed. Be the fastest to position your cards in such a way that only the objects appearing on the target card are visible. Keep your cool to find the right combination first.

name: Green Market Spinner Board Game
description: With illustrations as fresh as the produce it portrays, our Green Market Spinner Game is a fun way to play with fruits, vegetables, baked goods and more. Spin to collect products and be the first to complete your farm stand.

name: Crux
description: Created from a love of both climbing and card games, Crux is a simple yet strategic game to play. The concept is to draw cards to complete your problem while preventing your opponents from doing the same.

name: Picture Link
description:
Can you see a trumpet? How about a rabbit that's pink? Now mark a path between them in this clever game of links! Take turns calling out objects and marking off the spaces. Every board has the same pictures but found in different places. You don't want to help another player win, so be careful what you name. Be the first to link two sides together and Bingo! - You've won the game!

From the publisher:

Be the first to link two sides of the same color -- and win!

There's never a dull moment with Picture Link, as every player is involved on every move.

Players take turns calling out pictures and marking them bingo-style as they try to make a path from one side of their game board to the other.

Each game board has the same pictures in different locations, so with each call you may be helping another player as well as yourself!
mechanics: Network and Route Building, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition
publishers: Binary Arts, Gamewright, Jumbo, Smart Toys and Games, Inc., ThinkFun

name: Spell it!
description:
In Spell it!, one player rolls the five alphabet dice each round, then everyone tries to think of a word that uses three of the five letters in a word that fits the theme. The themes include: "Home Sweet Home", "Around the World", "Famous People", "Sports, Games, and Hobbies", "Create a Theme" and "No Nouns".

If you call out a word that matches the theme, you win a chip equal to the total number of letters used in that word.
categories: Dice, Educational, Party Game, Word Game

name: The Barons of Fyn
description:
BoneGames produces a number of do-it-yourself free games. You download a PDF containing rules and components, and print out what is required for play.

The Barons of Fyn is a card based strategy game in which competing players each try to become the most mighty Baron of Fyn.

The Great King Timothy has decided he will leave his kingdom, Fyn, and fight in the great crusades. While he is gone, he trusts the nobility of the land will behave themselves, as good nobles should. Little did King Timothy realize that his nobles were planning to use his leaving as a chance to conquer one another. Knowing the King could come back at any time, the Barons of Fyn each fought to get as much power as possible, so that when the King did return, he would be forced to ally himself with the most powerful Baron. As a result, the most powerful Baron would hold influence over the King, which could be used to punish the other Barons.

The Barons of Fyn starts with King Timothy leaving Fyn, and each player becoming one of the Barons who will fight it out for ultimate power. By expanding his frontiers, each Baron will build new villages, towns, and cities, which are loyal only to him. These villages, towns, and cities, then allow each Baron to build ever bigger armies with which the Baron can go conquering. The standard game is played until King Timothy returns to Fyn, at which point, the player with the most victory points is declared the winner.

Do you have what it takes to become the most mighty Baron of Fyn?

The game features a dynamic board that is generated as the players lay land cards; however, instead of a Kings-and-Things style board, this one combines some features of Illuminati, in the sense that each player's layout is independent of the others', except that when a group of cards is captured, the entire group is slid to your layout for hook-up, possibly discarding cards that can't fit (that would cause an overlap).

name: Wet Head
description:
From the Manufacturer:
A game of water roulette! 1) Strap on the water filled Wet Head; 2) Spin the top and pull out any one of the rods; 3) If you stay dry, pass Wet Head to the next player. Make Wet Head the perfect game for any season by adjusting the amount of water you use to play. Fill Wet Head to the brim when outside in the summer heat. Bring the fun indoors for winter by using a minimal amount of water. Summer or winter, the questions remains the same, "Will you be the next Wet Head?" Wethead has become a trending sensation during the Spring of 2016, being relicensed by Rudell Design LLC and relaunched by Zing Toys, worldwide. A free downloadable app offers questions that players can be asked to determine whether or not they are required to spin a spinner (provided) to see how many rods they must remove from the hat.
publishers: Happy Baobab, Imagination Games, Jumbo, Mattel, Inc., Zing Toys

name: Are You the Cultist? Intrigue Edition
description:
It’s the roaring 1920’s. The time is nigh. All clues indicate that the mansion is where nefarious Cultists are attempting to bring their dark god into this world. The group will investigate clues in and around the mansion, hopefully uncovering enough information that they can stop the looming threat. Little do they know that some of those Cultists are hidden among them. If the Cultists can hinder the Investigators enough, an avatar of the Old One will manifest and destroy the world as we know it.
The Intrigue Edition requires from 5 to 8 players. Investigators and Cultists go on a series of Investigations on the mansion or its grounds. Over 10 Investigations, try to deduce who are the hidden Cultists – or hide your identity as one. In the end, the side with the most points from successful Investigations wins.
categories: Bluffing, Deduction, Horror, Negotiation, Party Game
mechanics: Open Drafting, Simultaneous Action Selection, Team-Based Game

name: Alphas
description:
"Page 1, Byline of the Titan Front Newspaper. Submitted by H. Harvey Harris, Editor and Chief

Alphas. That's what the government called all these super power freaks. On this day, our city, our beloved Titan City, is crawling with these menaces! Each one, with their own agenda and their own way of possibly terrorizing the good people of the earth's mightiest city. But this editor in chief of yours will not simply sit idly, letting these vigilantes take the law into their own hands without being held accountable. I will be reporting daily from the front lines so stay tuned!"

The Titan Front Newspaper. Read by the entire city. For years it has painted the picture of Alphas being with its editor and chief as the main sounding board. The truth is, some Alphas are bad. Some use their powers for their own personal gain, or "just to see the world burn" as they say. Some just want to keep to themselves or... save themselves.

Some though... some hear the calling. Some believe that their abilities have with them, the responsibility to make the world a better place. A safer place.

Welcome to the world of Alphas, a world where the super powered are a regular sight.

Alphas is a super hero miniatures game for 2 to 4 players! The game uses a unique combat dice grading system paired with an Activation Deck System. Players can play the game 3 different ways!

Story Mode: Story mode takes the players through the graphic novel styled story, with a powerful narrative and an evolving story novel to novel. This mode will appeal to families and game groups alike as it can be played cooperatively!

"Head to Head" Mode: This mode involves building a team of Alphas and squaring off against 1-3 other teams of Alphas in a random 1 of 6 different objective based missions! This mode will appeal to any who like playing tactical competitive games, and will be supported with organized play after its release.

"One Shot" Mode: These modes will be expansions in the future that feature smaller story arcs for players to play through. The first of which will be "Alpha Hunters", a story where a shadow government group and it's giant mechanized creations hunt the Alphas, hurting cities and civilians in the process. These too can be played cooperatively, and yet... also competitively, because who would we be if we didn't let you play as the giant "miniature" Alpha Hunter Robots?!
